        <title>The lichen symbiosis re-viewed through the genomes of Cladonia grayi and its algal partner Asterochloris glomerata | BMC Genomics | Full Text</title>

        

    <meta name="citation_abstract" content="Lichens, encompassing 20,000 known species, are symbioses between specialized fungi (mycobionts), mostly ascomycetes, and unicellular green algae or cyanobacteria (photobionts). Here we describe the first parallel genomic analysis of the mycobiont Cladonia grayi and of its green algal photobiont Asterochloris glomerata. We focus on genes/predicted proteins of potential symbiotic significance, sought by surveying proteins differentially activated during early stages of mycobiont and photobiont interaction in coculture, expanded or contracted protein families, and proteins with differential rates of evolution. A) In coculture, the fungus upregulated small secreted proteins, membrane transport proteins, signal transduction components, extracellular hydrolases and, notably, a ribitol transporter and an ammonium transporter, and the alga activated DNA metabolism, signal transduction, and expression of flagellar components. B) Expanded fungal protein families include heterokaryon incompatibility proteins, polyketide synthases, and a unique set of G-protein &#945; subunit paralogs. Expanded algal protein families include carbohydrate active enzymes and a specific subclass of cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrases. The alga also appears to have acquired by horizontal gene transfer from prokaryotes novel archaeal ATPases and Desiccation-Related Proteins. Expanded in both symbionts are signal transduction components, ankyrin domain proteins and transcription factors involved in chromatin remodeling and stress responses. The fungal transportome is contracted, as are algal nitrate assimilation genes. C) In the mycobiont, slow-evolving proteins were enriched for components involved in protein translation, translocation and sorting. The surveyed genes affect stress resistance, signaling, genome reprogramming, nutritional and structural interactions. The alga carries many genes likely transferred horizontally through viruses, yet we found no evidence of inter-symbiont gene transfer. The presence in the photobiont of meiosis-specific genes supports the notion that sexual reproduction occurs in Asterochloris while they are free-living, a phenomenon with implications for the adaptability of lichens and the persistent autonomy of the symbionts. The diversity of the genes affecting the symbiosis suggests that lichens evolved by accretion of many scattered regulatory and structural changes rather than through introduction of a few key innovations. This predicts that paths to lichenization were variable in different phyla, which is consistent with the emerging consensus that ascolichens could have had a few independent origins."/>

    <meta name="journal_id" content="12864"/>

    <meta name="dc.title" content="The lichen symbiosis re-viewed through the genomes of Cladonia grayi and its algal partner Asterochloris glomerata"/>

    <meta name="dc.description" content="Lichens, encompassing 20,000 known species, are symbioses between specialized fungi (mycobionts), mostly ascomycetes, and unicellular green algae or cyanobacteria (photobionts). Here we describe the first parallel genomic analysis of the mycobiont Cladonia grayi and of its green algal photobiont Asterochloris glomerata. We focus on genes/predicted proteins of potential symbiotic significance, sought by surveying proteins differentially activated during early stages of mycobiont and photobiont interaction in coculture, expanded or contracted protein families, and proteins with differential rates of evolution. A) In coculture, the fungus upregulated small secreted proteins, membrane transport proteins, signal transduction components, extracellular hydrolases and, notably, a ribitol transporter and an ammonium transporter, and the alga activated DNA metabolism, signal transduction, and expression of flagellar components. B) Expanded fungal protein families include heterokaryon incompatibility proteins, polyketide synthases, and a unique set of G-protein &#945; subunit paralogs. Expanded algal protein families include carbohydrate active enzymes and a specific subclass of cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrases. The alga also appears to have acquired by horizontal gene transfer from prokaryotes novel archaeal ATPases and Desiccation-Related Proteins. Expanded in both symbionts are signal transduction components, ankyrin domain proteins and transcription factors involved in chromatin remodeling and stress responses. The fungal transportome is contracted, as are algal nitrate assimilation genes. C) In the mycobiont, slow-evolving proteins were enriched for components involved in protein translation, translocation and sorting. The surveyed genes affect stress resistance, signaling, genome reprogramming, nutritional and structural interactions. The alga carries many genes likely transferred horizontally through viruses, yet we found no evidence of inter-symbiont gene transfer. The presence in the photobiont of meiosis-specific genes supports the notion that sexual reproduction occurs in Asterochloris while they are free-living, a phenomenon with implications for the adaptability of lichens and the persistent autonomy of the symbionts. The diversity of the genes affecting the symbiosis suggests that lichens evolved by accretion of many scattered regulatory and structural changes rather than through introduction of a few key innovations. This predicts that paths to lichenization were variable in different phyla, which is consistent with the emerging consensus that ascolichens could have had a few independent origins."/>

    <meta name="description" content="Lichens, encompassing 20,000 known species, are symbioses between specialized fungi (mycobionts), mostly ascomycetes, and unicellular green algae or cyanobacteria (photobionts). Here we describe the first parallel genomic analysis of the mycobiont Cladonia grayi and of its green algal photobiont Asterochloris glomerata. B) Expanded fungal protein families include heterokaryon incompatibility proteins, polyketide synthases, and a unique set of G-protein &#945; subunit paralogs. Expanded algal protein families include carbohydrate active enzymes and a specific subclass of cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrases. The alga also appears to have acquired by horizontal gene transfer from prokaryotes novel archaeal ATPases and Desiccation-Related Proteins. Expanded in both symbionts are signal transduction components, ankyrin domain proteins and transcription factors involved in chromatin remodeling and stress responses. The fungal transportome is contracted, as are algal nitrate assimilation genes. C) In the mycobiont, slow-evolving proteins were enriched for components involved in protein translation, translocation and sorting.         <!--Polyfills CustomEvent constructor in IE. Allows us to use events to manage race conditions in client side js-->
<script>
    (function () {
        if ( typeof window.CustomEvent === "function" ) return false;
        function CustomEvent ( event, params ) {
            params = params || { bubbles: false, cancelable: false, detail: null };
            var evt = document.createEvent( 'CustomEvent' );
            evt.initCustomEvent( event, params.bubbles, params.cancelable, params.detail );
            return evt;
        }

        CustomEvent.prototype = window.Event.prototype;

        window.CustomEvent = CustomEvent;
    })();
</script>

        <script class="js-entry">
    if (window.config.mustardcut) {
        (function(w, d) {
            
            
            
                window.Component = {};
            

            var currentScript = d.currentScript || d.head.querySelector('script.js-entry');

            
            function catchNoModuleSupport() {
                var scriptEl = d.createElement('script');
                return (!('noModule' in scriptEl) && 'onbeforeload' in scriptEl)
            }

            var headScripts = [
                {'src': '/static/js/polyfill-es5-bundle-974eb189f7.js', 'async': false},
                {'src': '/static/js/airbrake-es5-bundle-07006365c1.js', 'async': false},
            ];

            var bodyScripts = [
                {'src': '/static/js/app-es5-bundle-b7e9f20f59.js', 'async': false, 'module': false},
                {'src': '/static/js/app-es6-bundle-0a469a101d.js', 'async': false, 'module': true}
                
                
                    , {'src': '/static/js/global-article-es5-bundle-8c8fdb8bd3.js', 'async': false, 'module': false},
                    {'src': '/static/js/global-article-es6-bundle-e6af530740.js', 'async': false, 'module': true}
                
            ];

            function createScript(script) {
                var scriptEl = d.createElement('script');
                scriptEl.src = script.src;
                scriptEl.async = script.async;
                if (script.module === true) {
                    scriptEl.type = "module";
                    if (catchNoModuleSupport()) {
                        scriptEl.src = '';
                    }
                } else if (script.module === false) {
                    scriptEl.setAttribute('nomodule', true)
                }
                if (script.charset) {
                    scriptEl.setAttribute('charset', script.charset);
                }

                return scriptEl;
            }

            for (var i = 0; i < headScripts.length; ++i) {
                var scriptEl = createScript(headScripts[i]);
                currentScript.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptEl, currentScript.nextSibling);
            }

            d.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
                for (var i = 0; i < bodyScripts.length; ++i) {
                    var scriptEl = createScript(bodyScripts[i]);
                    d.body.appendChild(scriptEl);
                }
            });

            // Webfont repeat view
            var config = w.config;
            if (config && config.publisherBrand && sessionStorage.fontsLoaded === 'true') {
                d.documentElement.className += ' webfonts-loaded';
            }
        })(window, document);
    }
</script>

    <script>
        function OptanonWrapper() {
            var elementInside = function(candidate, element) {
                if (candidate === element) {
                    return true;
                } else if (candidate.nodeName.toLowerCase() === 'body') {
                    return false;
                } else {
                    return elementInside(candidate.parentNode, element);
                }
            };

            var disclaimer = document.querySelector('.c-disclaimer[aria-hidden="false"]');
            window.dataLayer.push({event:'OneTrustGroupsUpdated'});
            if (disclaimer) {
                if (!elementInside(document.activeElement, disclaimer)) {
                    disclaimer.querySelector('button').focus();
                }
            } else {
                document.activeElement.blur();
            }
        }
    </script>

    <link rel="canonical" href="//bmcgenomics.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x"/>
    

        
        
        
        <meta property="og:url" content="https://bmcgenomics.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x"/>
        <meta property="og:type" content="article"/>
        <meta property="og:site_name" content="BMC Genomics"/>
        <meta property="og:title" content="The lichen symbiosis re-viewed through the genomes of Cladonia grayi and its algal partner Asterochloris glomerata"/>
        <meta property="og:description" content="Lichens, encompassing 20,000 known species, are symbioses between specialized fungi (mycobionts), mostly ascomycetes, and unicellular green algae or cyanobacteria (photobionts). Here we describe the first parallel genomic analysis of the mycobiont Cladonia grayi and of its green algal photobiont Asterochloris glomerata. We focus on genes/predicted proteins of potential symbiotic significance, sought by surveying proteins differentially activated during early stages of mycobiont and photobiont interaction in coculture, expanded or contracted protein families, and proteins with differential rates of evolution. A) In coculture, the fungus upregulated small secreted proteins, membrane transport proteins, signal transduction components, extracellular hydrolases and, notably, a ribitol transporter and an ammonium transporter, and the alga activated DNA metabolism, signal transduction, and expression of flagellar components. B) Expanded fungal protein families include heterokaryon incompatibility proteins, polyketide synthases, and a unique set of G-protein α subunit paralogs. Expanded algal protein families include carbohydrate active enzymes and a specific subclass of cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrases. The alga also appears to have acquired by horizontal gene transfer from prokaryotes novel archaeal ATPases and Desiccation-Related Proteins. Expanded in both symbionts are signal transduction components, ankyrin domain proteins and transcription factors involved in chromatin remodeling and stress responses. The fungal transportome is contracted, as are algal nitrate assimilation genes. C) In the mycobiont, slow-evolving proteins were enriched for components involved in protein translation, translocation and sorting. The surveyed genes affect stress resistance, signaling, genome reprogramming, nutritional and structural interactions. The alga carries many genes likely transferred horizontally through viruses, yet we found no evidence of inter-symbiont gene transfer. The presence in the photobiont of meiosis-specific genes supports the notion that sexual reproduction occurs in Asterochloris while they are free-living, a phenomenon with implications for the adaptability of lichens and the persistent autonomy of the symbionts. The diversity of the genes affecting the symbiosis suggests that lichens evolved by accretion of many scattered regulatory and structural changes rather than through introduction of a few key innovations. This predicts that paths to lichenization were variable in different phyla, which is consistent with the emerging consensus that ascolichens could have had a few independent origins."/>
        <meta property="og:image" content="https://media.springernature.com/w200/springer-static/cover/journal/12864.jpg"/>
    
        
    </head>

    <body class="journal journal-fulltext"

        <div class="u-container u-mt-32 u-mb-32 c-article-container u-clearfix" id="main-content" data-component="article-container">

            <main class="c-article-main-column u-float-left js-main-column" data-track-component="article body">
                
    <div class="c-pdf-download u-clear-both">
        <a href="//bmcgenomics.biomedcentral.com/track/pdf/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x.pdf" class="c-pdf-download__link" data-article-pdf="true"  data-readcube-pdf-url="true" data-test="pdf-link" data-draft-ignore="true" data-track="click" data-track-action="download pdf" data-track-label="link" data-track-external download>

                <article itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle" lang="en">
                    <div class="c-article-header">
                        

                        <ul class="c-article-identifiers" data-test="article-identifier">
                            
    
        <li class="c-article-identifiers__item" data-test="article-category">Research article</li>
    
    
        <li class="c-article-identifiers__item">
            <span class="c-article-identifiers__open" data-test="open-access">Open Access</span>
        </li>
    
    

                            <li class="c-article-identifiers__item"><a href="#article-info" data-track="click" data-track-action="publication date" data-track-label="link">Published: <time datetime="2019-07-23" itemprop="datePublished">23 July 2019</time></a></li>
                        </ul>

                        <h1 class="c-article-title" data-test="article-title" data-article-title="" itemprop="name headline">The lichen symbiosis re-viewed through the genomes of <i>Cladonia grayi</i> and its algal partner <i>Asterochloris glomerata</i></h1>

/><meta itemprop="address" content="0000 0000 9632 6718, grid.19006.3e, Department of Molecular, Cell, and Developmental Biology, and DOE Institute for Genomics and Proteomics, University of California, Los Angeles, USA" /></span></sup>, </li><li class="c-author-list__item" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a data-test="author-name" data-track="click" data-track-action="open author" data-track-label="link" href="#auth-Nimrod-Rubinstein" data-author-popup="auth-Nimrod-Rubinstein">Nimrod Rubinstein</a></span><sup class="u-js-hide"><a href="#Aff20">20</a>,<a href="#Aff21">21</a><span itemprop="affiliation" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" class="u-visually-hidden"><meta itemprop="name" content="National Evolutionary Synthesis Center" /><meta itemprop="address" content="0000 0000 9027 3547, grid.419343.8, National Evolutionary Synthesis Center, Durham, USA" /></span><span itemprop="affiliation" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" class="u-visually-hidden"><meta itemprop="name" content="Calico Life Sciences LLC" /><meta itemprop="address" content="Calico Life Sciences LLC, South San Francisco, USA" /></span></sup>, </li><li class="c-author-list__item" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a data-test="author-name" data-track="click" data-track-action="open author" data-track-label="link" href="#auth-Maria_Virginia-Sanchez_Puerta" data-author-popup="auth-Maria_Virginia-Sanchez_Puerta">Maria Virginia Sanchez-Puerta</a></span><sup class="u-js-hide"><a href="#Aff22">22</a><span itemprop="affiliation" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" class="u-visually-hidden"><meta itemprop="name" content="Universidad Nacional de Cuyo" /><meta itemprop="address" content="0000 0001 2185 5065, grid.412108.e, IBAM, Facultad de Ciencias Agrarias, CONICET, Universidad Nacional de Cuyo, Chacras de Coria, Argentina" /></span></sup>, </li><li class="c-author-list__item" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a data-test="author-name" data-track="click" data-track-action="open Talbot</a></span><sup class="u-js-hide"><a href="#Aff27">27</a><span itemprop="affiliation" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" class="u-visually-hidden"><meta itemprop="name" content="Norwich Research Park" /><meta itemprop="address" content="grid.420132.6, The Sainsbury Laboratory, Norwich Research Park, Norwich, UK" /></span></sup>, </li><li class="c-author-list__item" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a data-test="author-name" data-track="click" data-track-action="open author" data-track-label="link" href="#auth-Claire-Veneault_Fourrey" data-author-popup="auth-Claire-Veneault_Fourrey">Claire Veneault-Fourrey</a></span><sup class="u-js-hide"><a href="#Aff13">13</a>,<a href="#Aff28">28</a><span itemprop="affiliation" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" class="u-visually-hidden"><meta itemprop="name" content="INRA, Université de Lorraine, Interactions Arbres-Microorganismes, INRA-Nancy" /><meta itemprop="address" content="grid.418108.4, INRA, Université de Lorraine, Interactions Arbres-Microorganismes, INRA-Nancy, Champenoux, France" /></span><span itemprop="affiliation" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" class="u-visually-hidden"><meta itemprop="name" content="Université de Lorraine, INRA, Interactions Arbres-Microorganismes, Faculté des Sciences et Technologies" /><meta itemprop="address" content="Université de Lorraine, INRA, Interactions Arbres-Microorganismes, Faculté des Sciences et Technologies, Vandoeuvre les Nancy Cedex, France" /></span></sup> &amp; </li><li class="c-author-list__item" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name"><a data-test="author-name" data-track="click" data-track-action="open author" data-track-label="link" href="#auth-Basil_B_-Xavier" data-author-popup="auth-Basil_B_-Xavier">Basil B. Xavier</a></span><sup class="u-js-hide"><a href="#Aff3">3</a>,<a href="#Aff29">29</a><span itemprop="affiliation" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" class="u-visually-hidden"><meta itemprop="name" content="University of Iceland" /><meta itemprop="address" content="0000 0004 0640 0021, grid.14013.37, Faculty of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Iceland, Reykjavík, Iceland" /></span><span itemprop="affiliation" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" class="u-visually-hidden"><meta itemprop="name" content="University of Antwerp" /><meta itemprop="address" content="0000 0001 0790 3681, grid.5284.b, Laboratory of Medical Microbiology, Vaccine &amp; Infectious Disease Institute, University of Antwerp, Antwerp, Belgium" /></span></sup> </li></ul>
                        <p class="c-article-info-details" data-container-section="info">
                            
    <a data-test="journal-link" href="/"><i data-test="journal-title">BMC Genomics</i></a>

                    <section aria-labelledby="Abs1" data-title="Abstract" lang="en"><div class="c-article-section" id="Abs1-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Abs1">Abstract</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Abs1-content"><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" data-test="abstract-sub-heading">Background</h3><p>Lichens, encompassing 20,000 known species, are symbioses between specialized fungi (mycobionts), mostly ascomycetes, and unicellular green algae or cyanobacteria (photobionts). Here we describe the first parallel genomic analysis of the mycobiont <i>Cladonia grayi</i> and of its green algal photobiont <i>Asterochloris glomerata</i>. We focus on genes/predicted proteins of potential symbiotic significance, sought by surveying proteins differentially activated during early stages of mycobiont and photobiont interaction in coculture, expanded or contracted protein families, and proteins with differential rates of evolution.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" data-test="abstract-sub-heading">Results</h3><p>A) In coculture, the fungus upregulated small secreted proteins, membrane transport proteins, signal transduction components, extracellular hydrolases and, notably, a ribitol transporter and an ammonium transporter, and the alga activated DNA metabolism, signal transduction, and expression of flagellar components. B) Expanded fungal protein families include heterokaryon incompatibility proteins, polyketide synthases, and a unique set of G-protein α subunit paralogs. Expanded algal protein families include carbohydrate active enzymes and a specific subclass of cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrases. The alga also appears to have acquired by horizontal gene transfer from prokaryotes novel archaeal ATPases and Desiccation-Related Proteins. Expanded in both symbionts are signal transduction components, ankyrin domain proteins and transcription factors involved in chromatin remodeling and stress responses. The fungal transportome is contracted, as are algal nitrate assimilation genes. C) In the mycobiont, slow-evolving proteins were enriched for components involved in protein translation, translocation and sorting.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" data-test="abstract-sub-heading">Conclusions</h3><p>The surveyed genes affect stress resistance, signaling, genome reprogramming, nutritional and structural interactions. The alga carries many genes likely transferred horizontally through viruses, yet we found no evidence of inter-symbiont gene transfer. The presence in the photobiont of meiosis-specific genes supports the notion that sexual reproduction occurs in <i>Asterochloris</i> while they are free-living, a phenomenon with implications for the adaptability of lichens and the persistent autonomy of the symbionts. The diversity of the genes affecting the symbiosis suggests that lichens evolved by accretion of many scattered regulatory and structural changes rather than through introduction of a few key innovations. This predicts that paths to lichenization were variable in different phyla, which is consistent with the emerging consensus that ascolichens could have had a few independent origins.</p></div></div></section>
                    
    


                    <section aria-labelledby="Sec1" data-title="Background"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec1-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec1">Background</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec1-content"><p>Simon Schwendener in 1869 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 1" title="Honegger R. Great Discoveries in bryology and lichenology - Simon Schwendener (1829-1919) and the Dual Hypothesis of Lichens. Bryologist. 2000;103(2):307–13." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR1" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2262">1</a>] correctly recognized lichens as intimate symbioses between specialized fungi and phototrophic unicellular green algae as the main symbionts. Cyanobacteria were later recognized also as primary phototrophs in many lichens. In addition to the main symbiotic partners, lichens harbor diverse communities of prokaryotes and fungi as cohabitants [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="U'Ren JM, Lutzoni F, Miadlikowska J, Laetsch AD, Arnold AE. Host and geographic structure of endophytic and endolichenic fungi at a continental scale. Am J Bot. 2012;99(5):898–914." href="#ref-CR2" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2265">2</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Grube M, Wedin M. Lichenized Fungi and the Evolution of Symbiotic Organization. Microbiol Spectr. 2016;4(6):1–17." href="#ref-CR3" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2265_1">3</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Arnold AE, Miadlikowska J, Higgins KL, Sarvate SD, Gugger P, Way A, Hofstetter V, Kauff F, Lutzoni F. A Phylogenetic Estimation of Trophic Transition Networks for Ascomycetous Fungi: Are Lichens Cradles of Symbiotrophic Fungal Diversification? Syst Biol. 2009;58(3):283–97." href="#ref-CR4" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2265_2">4</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Grube M, Cardinale M, de Castro JV Jr, Muller H, Berg G. Species-specific structural and functional diversity of bacterial communities in lichen symbioses. ISME J. 2009;3(9):1105–15." href="#ref-CR5" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2265_3">5</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 6" title="Hodkinson BP, Gottel NR, Schadt CW, Lutzoni F. Photoautotrophic symbiont and geography are major factors affecting highly structured and diverse bacterial communities in the lichen microbiome. Environ Microbiol. 2012;14(1):147–61." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR6" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2268">6</a>]. Recently, highly coevolved basidiomycete yeasts were discovered in the cortex of many lichens [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 7" title="Spribille T, Tuovinen V, Resl P, Vanderpool D, Wolinski H, Aime MC, Schneider K, Stabentheiner E, Toome-Heller M, Thor G, et al. Basidiomycete yeasts in the cortex of ascomycete macrolichens. Science. 2016;353(6298):488–92." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR7" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2271">7</a>], sometimes causing disease [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 8" title="Ana M, Millanes PD, Wedin M. Cyphobasidium gen. nov., a new lichen-inhabiting lineage in the Cystobasidiomycetes (Pucciniomycotina, Basidiomycota, Fungi). Fungal Biol. 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR8" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2274">8</a>]. The detailed interactions of the various cohabitants with the main symbionts are being investigated [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 9" title="Grube M, Cernava T, Soh J, Fuchs S, Aschenbrenner I, Lassek C, Wegner U, Becher D, Riedel K, Sensen CW, et al. Exploring functional contexts of symbiotic sustain within lichen-associated bacteria by comparative omics. ISME J. 2014." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR9" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2278">9</a>]. Typically, lichens thrive in above-ground niches with limited water in diverse environments, often withstanding extreme heat, desiccation, or cold [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 3" title="Grube M, Wedin M. Lichenized Fungi and the Evolution of Symbiotic Organization. Microbiol Spectr. 2016;4(6):1–17." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR3" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2281">3</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 10" title="Honegger R. The symbiotic phenotype of lichen-forming ascomycetes and their endo- and epibionts. In: Hock B, editor. Fungal Associations, vol. 9. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer; 2012. p. 287–339. ISBN 978-3-642-30825-3." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR10" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2284">10</a>]. Widespread across terrestrial ecosystems, often dominant carbon and nitrogen fixers in alpine, subalpine, and high latitude habitats, the estimated 18,000 to 20,000 lichen species [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 11" title="Feuerer T, Hawksworth DL. Biodiversity of lichens, including a world-wide analysis of checklist data based on Takhtajan’s floristic regions. Biodivers Conserv. 2007;16(1):85–98." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR11" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2287">11</a>], mostly ascomycetes, represent about 20% of all known fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 12" title="Ainsworth &amp; Bisby’s Dictionary of the Fungi. 9th edn. Wallingford: CAB International: Cambridge University Press; 2001." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR12" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2290">12</a>]. There are only about 120 lichen phototroph species (photobionts) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 10" title="Honegger R. The symbiotic phenotype of lichen-forming ascomycetes and their endo- and epibionts. In: Hock B, editor. Fungal Associations, vol. 9. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer; 2012. p. 287–339. ISBN 978-3-642-30825-3." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR10" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2293">10</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 13" title="Rambold G, Friedl T, Beck A. Photobionts in lichens: Possible indicators of phylogenetic relationships? Bryologist. 1998;101(3):392–7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR13" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2297">13</a>], far fewer than the 20,000 known lichen fungal species (mycobionts). Lichens are named based on their mycobiont since the fungus is the most conspicuous partner and since the same photobiont species (alga or cyanobacterium) can be found in several different lichens.</p><p>Lichens can reproduce somatically through propagules comprising both symbionts, or sexually through meiotic fungal spores that must combine with the appropriate photobiont to re-form a lichen. Sexual reproduction is not commonly seen in trebouxoid lichen algae, although evidence supporting it has been found (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec6">Heterothallism probably evolved from homothallism in Cladonia; genetic evidence for sex in Asterochloris</a> section). Lichens are well known for their unique and abundantly produced secondary metabolites [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 14" title="Culberson CF. Chemical and botanical guide to lichen products. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press; 1969." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR14" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2306">14</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 15" title="Huneck S. The significance of lichens and their metabolites. Naturwissenschaften. 1999;86(12):559–70." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR15" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2309">15</a>]. The genetic, physiological, and structural integration of mycobionts and photobionts has produced a vast array of beautifully differentiated partnerships [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 16" title="Lichens Home Page. 
                    http://www.sharnoffphotos.com/lichens/lichens_home_index.html
                    
                  ." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR16" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2312">16</a>], with only occasional instability [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Richardson DHS. War in the world of lichens: parasitism and symbiosis as exemplified by lichens and lichenicolous fungi. Mycol Res. 1999;103:641–50." href="#ref-CR17" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2315">17</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Wedin M, Doring H, Gilenstam G. Saprotrophy and lichenization as options for the same fungal species on different substrata: environmental plasticity and fungal lifestyles in the Stictis-Conotrema complex. New Phytol. 2004;164(3):459–65." href="#ref-CR18" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2315_1">18</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 19" title="Muggia L, Baloch E, Stabentheiner E, Grube M, Wedin M. Photobiont association and genetic diversity of the optionally lichenized fungus Schizoxylon albescens. Fems Microbiol Ecol. 2011;75(2):255–72." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR19" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2319">19</a>]. The fungal and lichen fossil record [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 20" title="Honegger R, Edwards D, Axe L. The earliest records of internally stratified cyanobacterial and algal lichens from the Lower Devonian of the Welsh Borderland. New Phytol. 2013;197(1):264–75." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR20" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2322">20</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 21" title="Berbee ML, Taylor JW. Dating the molecular clock in fungi – how close are we? Fungal Biol Rev. 2010;24(1-2):1–16." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR21" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2325">21</a>] has placed fossils resembling extant lichen taxa in the Devonian-early Carboniferous, 415–350 million years ago, and perhaps simpler mycobiont-photobiont associations even earlier [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 22" title="Taylor TN, Hass H, Kerp H. A cyanolichen from the Lower Devonian Rhynie chert. Am J Bot. 1997;84(7):992–1004." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR22" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2328">22</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 23" title="Yuan XL, Xiao SH, Taylor TN. Lichen-like symbiosis 600 million years ago. Science. 2005;308(5724):1017–20." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR23" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2331">23</a>]. Despite their intimate coexistence for hundreds of millions of years and the construction of complex interfaces between them [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 10" title="Honegger R. The symbiotic phenotype of lichen-forming ascomycetes and their endo- and epibionts. In: Hock B, editor. Fungal Associations, vol. 9. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer; 2012. p. 287–339. ISBN 978-3-642-30825-3." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR10" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2334">10</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 24" title="Lee JH, Heuser JE, Roth R, Goodenough U. Eisosome Ultrastructure and Evolution in Fungi, Microalgae, and Lichens. Eukaryot Cell. 2015;14(10):1017–42." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR24" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2338">24</a>], lichen symbionts have not lost their genetic and cellular independence. Cell membranes are not breached in their interactions and genomes are not merged, although some have extended to lichens the concept of genome acquisition [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 25" title="Margulis L, Sagan D. Acquiring Genomes: a theory of the origin of species. New York: Basic Books; 2002." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR25" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2341">25</a>]. There is no evidence of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) between the symbionts, yet both have acquired genes from other sources (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec5">A low-GC region in Asterochloris is a remnant of a large virus insertion, an HGT-mediator</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec10">Inferences from differential transcription about nutritional fluxes at the symbiotic interface</a>, and <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec14">Photobiont expanded families</a> sections). The partners of many lichens have been isolated and grown separately in axenic culture, but free-living stages of lichen fungi and their algae remain mostly cryptic in nature [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 18" title="Wedin M, Doring H, Gilenstam G. Saprotrophy and lichenization as options for the same fungal species on different substrata: environmental plasticity and fungal lifestyles in the Stictis-Conotrema complex. New Phytol. 2004;164(3):459–65." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR18" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2353">18</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Ahmadjian V. The Lichen Alga Trebouxia - Does It Occur Free-Living? Plant Syst Evol. 1988;158(2-4):243–7." href="#ref-CR26" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2357">26</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Bubrick P, Galun M, Frensdorff A. Observations on free-living Trebouxia De Puymaly and Pseudotrebouxia Archibald, and evidence that both symbionts from Xanthoria parietina (L.) TH.FR. can be found free-living in nature. The New Phytolt. 1984;97:455–62." href="#ref-CR27" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2357_1">27</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Tuovinen V, Svensson M, Kubartova A, Ottosson E, Stenlid J, Thor G, Dahlberg A. No support for occurrence of free-living Cladonia mycobionts in dead wood. Fungal Ecol. 2015;14:130–2." href="#ref-CR28" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2357_2">28</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 29" title="Sanders WB. Observing microscopic phases of lichen life cycles on transparent substrata placed in situ. Lichenologist. 2005;37:373–82." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR29" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2360">29</a>]. However, these stages are not insignificant for the lichen life cycle [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 29" title="Sanders WB. Observing microscopic phases of lichen life cycles on transparent substrata placed in situ. Lichenologist. 2005;37:373–82." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR29" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2363">29</a>]. The laboratory reconstitution of cultured lichen symbionts into fully developed lichens has a checkered history [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 30" title="Stocker-Worgotter E. New frontiers in bryology and lichenology - Experimental lichenology and microbiology of lichens: Culture experiments, secondary chemistry of cultured mycobionts, resynthesis, and thallus morphogenesis. Bryologist. 2001;104(4):576–81." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR30" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2366">30</a>], where the reproducibility needed for molecular investigations is still elusive. Molecular studies addressing functional aspects of this mutualistic symbiosis are few [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 9" title="Grube M, Cernava T, Soh J, Fuchs S, Aschenbrenner I, Lassek C, Wegner U, Becher D, Riedel K, Sensen CW, et al. Exploring functional contexts of symbiotic sustain within lichen-associated bacteria by comparative omics. ISME J. 2014." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR9" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2369">9</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Armaleo D, Miao V. Symbiosis and DNA methylation in the Cladonia lichen fungus. Symbiosis. 1999;26(2):143–63." href="#ref-CR31" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2372">31</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Trembley ML, Ringli C, Honegger R. Morphological and molecular analysis of early stages in the resynthesis of the lichen Baeomyces rufus. Mycol Res. 2002;106:768–76." href="#ref-CR32" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2372_1">32</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Joneson S, Armaleo D, Lutzoni F. Fungal and algal gene expression in early developmental stages of lichen-symbiosis. Mycologia. 2011;103(2):291–306." href="#ref-CR33" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2372_2">33</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Armaleo D, Sun XM, Culberson C. Insights from the first putative biosynthetic gene cluster for a lichen depside and depsidone. Mycologia. 2011;103(4):741–54." href="#ref-CR34" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2372_3">34</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 35" title="DePriest PT. Early molecular investigations of lichen-forming symbionts: 1986-2001. Annu Rev Microbiol. 2004;58:273–301." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR35" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2376">35</a>], but the recent publication of several lichen -omics papers and datasets [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 9" title="Grube M, Cernava T, Soh J, Fuchs S, Aschenbrenner I, Lassek C, Wegner U, Becher D, Riedel K, Sensen CW, et al. Exploring functional contexts of symbiotic sustain within lichen-associated bacteria by comparative omics. ISME J. 2014." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR9" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2379">9</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Grube M, Berg G, Andrésson ÓS, Vilhelmsson O, Dyer PS, VPW M. Lichen Genomics: Prospects and Progress. In: Martin F, editor. The Ecological Genomics of Fungi. Hoboken: Wiley; 2014. p. 191–212." href="#ref-CR36" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382">36</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Schneider T, Schmid E, de Castro JV Jr, Cardinale M, Eberl L, Grube M, Berg G, Riedel K. Structure and function of the symbiosis partners of the lung lichen (Lobaria pulmonaria L. Hoffm.) analyzed by metaproteomics. Proteomics. 2011;11(13):2752–6." href="#ref-CR37" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_1">37</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Junttila S, Rudd S. Characterization of a transcriptome from a non-model organism, Cladonia rangiferina, the grey reindeer lichen, using high-throughput next generation sequencing and EST sequence data. Bmc Genomics. 2012;13:575." href="#ref-CR38" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_2">38</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Junttila S, Laiho A, Gyenesei A, Rudd S. Whole transcriptome characterization of the effects of dehydration and rehydration on Cladonia rangiferina, the grey reindeer lichen. Bmc Genomics. 2013;14:870." href="#ref-CR39" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_3">39</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Park SY, Choi J, Kim JA, Jeong MH, Kim S, Lee YH, Hur JS. Draft Genome Sequence of Cladonia macilenta KoLRI003786, a Lichen-Forming Fungus Producing Biruloquinone. Genome Announc. 2013;1(5)." href="#ref-CR40" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_4">40</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Park SY, Choi J, Lee GW, Kim JA, Oh SO, Jeong MH, Yu NH, Kim S, Lee YH, Hur JS. Draft Genome Sequence of Lichen-Forming Fungus Cladonia metacorallifera Strain KoLRI002260. Genome Announc. 2014;2(1)." href="#ref-CR41" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_5">41</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Wang YY, Liu B, Zhang XY, Zhou QM, Zhang T, Li H, Yu YF, Zhang XL, Hao XY, Wang M, et al. Genome characteristics reveal the impact of lichenization on lichen-forming fungus Endocarpon pusillum Hedwig (Verrucariales, Ascomycota). Bmc Genomics. 2014;15:34." href="#ref-CR42" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_6">42</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Munzi S, Sheppard LJ, Leith ID, Cruz C, Branquinho C, Bini L, Gagliardi A, Cai G, Parrotta L. The cost of surviving nitrogen excess: energy and protein demand in the lichen Cladonia portentosa as revealed by proteomic analysis. Planta. 2017." href="#ref-CR43" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_7">43</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Carniel FC, Gerdol M, Montagner A, Banchi E, De Moro G, Manfrin C, Muggia L, Pallavicini A, Tretiach M. New features of desiccation tolerance in the lichen photobiont Trebouxia gelatinosa are revealed by a transcriptomic approach. Plant Mol Biol. 2016;91(3):319–39." href="#ref-CR44" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_8">44</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Dal Grande F, Meiser A, Tzovaras BG, Otte J, Ebersberger I, Schmitt I. The draft genome of the lichen-forming fungus Lasallia hispanica (Frey) Sancho &amp; A. Crespo. Lichenologist. 2018;50(3):329–40." href="#ref-CR45" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2382_9">45</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 46" title="McDonald TR, Mueller O, Dietrich FS, Lutzoni F. High-throughput genome sequencing of lichenizing fungi to assess gene loss in the ammonium transporter/ammonia permease gene family. Bmc Genomics. 2013;14." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR46" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2385">46</a>] heralds expansion of this field.</p><p>Here we present the first parallel genomic analysis of both primary symbionts in a lichen, the fungus (mycobiont) <i>Cladonia grayi</i> and the alga (photobiont) <i>Asterochloris glomerata</i>, and use several approaches to identify genes/proteins of potential symbiotic relevance. Our analysis is based exclusively on the symbionts’ nucleic acid sequences, and the proteins involved are predicted. <i>Cladonia grayi</i> (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig1">1</a>) belongs to a genus with worldwide distribution, part of the class of Lecanoromycetes that includes 70% of the known lichens [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 47" title="Erikkson OE. Outline of Ascomycota. In:  Myconet, vol. 12; 2006. p. 1–82." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR47" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2403">47</a>] (phylum Ascomycota, subphylum Pezizomycotina). The unicellular photobiont, <i>A. glomerata</i>, belongs to the most common order of lichen algae, the Trebouxiales [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 13" title="Rambold G, Friedl T, Beck A. Photobionts in lichens: Possible indicators of phylogenetic relationships? Bryologist. 1998;101(3):392–7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR13" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2410">13</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 48" title="Skaloud P, Peksa O. Evolutionary inferences based on ITS rDNA and actin sequences reveal extensive diversity of the common lichen alga Asterochloris (Trebouxiophyceae, Chlorophyta). Mol Phylogenet Evol. 2010;54(1):36–46." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR48" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2413">48</a>]<i>.</i> There are few sequenced genomes from unicellular chlorophyte algae [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Merchant SS, Prochnik SE, Vallon O, Harris EH, Karpowicz SJ, Witman GB, Terry A, Salamov A, Fritz-Laylin LK, Marechal-Drouard L, et al. The Chlamydomonas genome reveals the evolution of key animal and plant functions. Science. 2007;318(5848):245–51." href="#ref-CR49" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2419">49</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Blanc G, Duncan G, Agarkova I, Borodovsky M, Gurnon J, Kuo A, Lindquist E, Lucas S, Pangilinan J, Polle J, et al. The Chlorella variabilis NC64A Genome Reveals Adaptation to Photosymbiosis, Coevolution with Viruses, and Cryptic Sex. Plant Cell. 2010;22(9):2943–55." href="#ref-CR50" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2419_1">50</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Umen J, Prochnik SE, Nedelcu AM, Hallmann A, Miller SM, Nishii I, Ferris P, Kuo A, Mitros T, Fritz-Laylin LK, et al. Genomic Analysis of Organismal Complexity in the Multicellular Green Alga Volvox carteri. Science. 2010;329(5988):223–6." href="#ref-CR51" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2419_2">51</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Leliaert F, Smith DR, Moreau H, Herron MD, Verbruggen H, Delwiche CF, De Clerck O. Phylogeny and molecular evolution of the green algae. Critical Reviews in Plant Sciences. 2011;31(1):1–46." href="#ref-CR52" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2419_3">52</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Bowler C, Tirichine L. Decoding algal genomes: tracing back the history of photosynthetic life on Earth. Plant J. 2011;66(1):45–57." href="#ref-CR53" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2419_4">53</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Blanc G, Agarkova I, Grimwood J, Kuo A, Brueggeman A, Dunigan DD, Gurnon J, Ladunga I, Lindquist E, Lucas S, et al. The genome of the polar eukaryotic microalga Coccomyxa subellipsoidea reveals traits of cold adaptation. Genome Biol. 2012;13(5):R39." href="#ref-CR54" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2419_5">54</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 55" title="Roth MS, Cokus SJ, Gallaher SD, Walter A, Lopez D, Erickson E, Endelman B, Westcott D, Larabell CA, Merchant SS, et al. Chromosome-level genome assembly and transcriptome of the green alga Chromochloris zofingiensis illuminates astaxanthin production. P Natl Acad Sci USA. 2017;114(21):E4296–305." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR55" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2422">55</a>]: some are naturally free-living and some, like <i>Coccomyxa subellipsoidea</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 54" title="Blanc G, Agarkova I, Grimwood J, Kuo A, Brueggeman A, Dunigan DD, Gurnon J, Ladunga I, Lindquist E, Lucas S, et al. The genome of the polar eukaryotic microalga Coccomyxa subellipsoidea reveals traits of cold adaptation. Genome Biol. 2012;13(5):R39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR54" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2429">54</a>] and <i>Chlorella variabilis</i>, are facultative symbionts [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 50" title="Blanc G, Duncan G, Agarkova I, Borodovsky M, Gurnon J, Kuo A, Lindquist E, Lucas S, Pangilinan J, Polle J, et al. The Chlorella variabilis NC64A Genome Reveals Adaptation to Photosymbiosis, Coevolution with Viruses, and Cryptic Sex. Plant Cell. 2010;22(9):2943–55." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR50" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2435">50</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 54" title="Blanc G, Agarkova I, Grimwood J, Kuo A, Brueggeman A, Dunigan DD, Gurnon J, Ladunga I, Lindquist E, Lucas S, et al. The genome of the polar eukaryotic microalga Coccomyxa subellipsoidea reveals traits of cold adaptation. Genome Biol. 2012;13(5):R39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR54" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2438">54</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 56" title="Zoller S, Lutzoni F. Slow algae, fast fungi: exceptionally high nucleotide substitution rate differences between lichenized fungi Omphalina and their symbiotic green algae Coccomyxa. Mol Phylogenet Evol. 2003;29(3):629–40." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR56" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2441">56</a>]. Genomic analysis of lichens will not only increase the molecular and ecological understanding of a large and understudied portion of the fungal and algal phyla but also complement the emerging genomics of other symbioses involving mycorrhizal [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Martin F, Aerts A, Ahren D, Brun A, Danchin EGJ, Duchaussoy F, Gibon J, Kohler A, Lindquist E, Pereda V, et al. The genome of Laccaria bicolor provides insights into mycorrhizal symbiosis. Nature. 2008;452(7183):88–U87." href="#ref-CR57" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2445">57</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Martin F, Kohler A, Murat C, Balestrini R, Coutinho PM, Jaillon O, Montanini B, Morin E, Noel B, Percudani R, et al. Perigord black truffle genome uncovers evolutionary origins and mechanisms of symbiosis. Nature. 2010;464(7291):1033–8." href="#ref-CR58" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2445_1">58</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Gomez SK, Javot H, Deewatthanawong P, Torres-Jerez I, Tang YH, Blancaflor EB, Udvardi MK, Harrison MJ. Medicago truncatula and Glomus intraradices gene expression in cortical cells harboring arbuscules in the arbuscular mycorrhizal symbiosis. Bmc Plant Biol. 2009;9." href="#ref-CR59" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2445_2">59</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 60" title="Tisserant E, Malbreil M, Kuo A, Kohler A, Symeonidi A, Balestrini R, Charron P, Duensing N, Frey NFD, Gianinazzi-Pearson V, et al. Genome of an arbuscular mycorrhizal fungus provides insight into the oldest plant symbiosis. P Natl Acad Sci USA. 2013;110(50):20117–22." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR60" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2448">60</a>], endophytic [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 61" title="Rodriguez RJ, White JF, Arnold AE, Redman RS. Fungal endophytes: diversity and functional roles. New Phytol. 2009;182(2):314–30." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR61" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2451">61</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 62" title="Kaul S, Sharma T, Dhar MK. “Omics” Tools for Better Understanding the Plant-Endophyte Interactions. Front Plant Sci. 2016;7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR62" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2454">62</a>], or plant pathogenic fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 63" title="Dean R, Van Kan JAL, Pretorius ZA, Hammond-Kosack KE, Di Pietro A, Spanu PD, Rudd JJ, Dickman M, Kahmann R, Ellis J, et al. The Top 10 fungal pathogens in molecular plant pathology. Mol Plant Pathol. 2012;13(4):414–30." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR63" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2457">63</a>].</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-1" data-title="Fig. 1"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig1" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 1</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/1" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig1_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-1-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig1_HTML.png" alt="figure1" loading="lazy" width="685" height="814"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-1-desc"><p>The lichen <i>Cladonia grayi</i>. The most conspicuous parts of the <i>Cladonia</i> thallus are the goblet-shaped podetia that support the sexual and vegetative reproductive structures: the goblets’ upper margins are covered with brown fungal apothecia, sites of meiotic spore production and ejection into the air; the podetial surfaces are covered with green vegetative propagules called soredia, which are tiny alga-fungus packets detached by rain and wind and able to grow and differentiate into full thalli. Soredia are continuously produced and extruded onto the podetial surface from the underlying fungal tissue, which has algae embedded in it. The ground is covered with the less conspicuous, leaf-shaped parts of <i>Cladonia</i> called squamules (yellow arrowhead), which are tiny but fully differentiated lichen thalli with typical medullar, algal, and cortical layers. The grass-like bodies are bryophyte initials. The focus-stacked photograph was taken in D.A.’s lab by Thomas Barlow, who holds the copyright and consents to its use in this study</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/1" data-track-dest="link:Figure1 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div></div></div></section><section aria-labelledby="Sec2" data-title="Results and discussion"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec2-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec2">Results and discussion</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec2-content"><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec3">General characteristics of the <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> genomes</h3><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec4">Genome sizes and gene organization</h4><p>The mycobiont is a single-spore isolate from <i>C. grayi</i> and the photobiont is <i>Asterochloris glomerata</i> isolated from <i>C. grayi</i> soredia [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 64" title="Armaleo D, May S. Sizing the fungal and algal genomes of the lichen Cladonia grayi through quantitative PCR. Symbiosis. 2009;49(1):43–51." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR64" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2519">64</a>]. Table&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Tab1">1</a> includes basic features of the two nuclear and the three organelle genomes. Organelle genomes are briefly discussed in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM1">1</a>, and details are in Xavier et al. [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 65" title="Xavier BB, Miao VPW, Jonsson ZO, Andresson OS. Mitochondrial genomes from the lichenized fungi Peltigera membranacea and Peltigera malacea: Features and phylogeny. Fungal Biol. 2012;116(7):802–14." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR65" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2529">65</a>] and Xavier’s thesis [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 66" title="Organelle Genomes of Lichens. 
                    https://skemman.is/bitstream/1946/10803/1/BBX_MS_Dissertation.pdf
                    
                  ." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR66" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2532">66</a>]. Whole genome assemblies and annotations are at [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 67" title="Institute DJG. Cladonia grayi Cgr/DA2myc/ss v2.0. Available from: 
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Clagr3/Clagr3.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 8 Aug 2018." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR67" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2535">67</a>] for the mycobiont and at [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 68" title="Institute DJG. Asterochloris sp. Cgr/DA1pho v2.0. Available from: 
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Astpho2/Astpho2.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 8 Aug 2018." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR68" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2538">68</a>] for the photobiont. Relationships of <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A.glomerata</i> within broad phylogenetic contexts, genome sizes, and proportions of repeated and unique sequences are shown in Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig2">2</a>. The nuclear genomes of lichen symbionts are not reduced in size nor gene content compared to free-living relatives, in contrast to the reductions observed in many host-dependent bacteria [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 69" title="McCutcheon JP, Moran NA. Extreme genome reduction in symbiotic bacteria. Nat Rev Microbiol. 2012;10(1):13–26." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR69" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2551">69</a>]. With its 35 Mb genome and 11,400 gene models, the <i>C. grayi</i> mycobiont falls in the average size range for most Ascomycota [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 70" title="Gregory TR, Nicol JA, Tamm H, Kullman B, Kullman K, Leitch IJ, Murray BG, Kapraun DF, Greilhuber J, Bennett MD. Eukaryotic genome size databases. Nucleic Acids Res. 2007;35(Database issue):D332–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR70" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2557">70</a>]. Other lichen fungi fall in the same range, between 26 and 59 Mb [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 46" title="McDonald TR, Mueller O, Dietrich FS, Lutzoni F. High-throughput genome sequencing of lichenizing fungi to assess gene loss in the ammonium transporter/ammonia permease gene family. Bmc Genomics. 2013;14." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR46" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2560">46</a>]. Large increases in the number of transposable elements significantly affect genome size in many biotrophic fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 71" title="Spanu PD. The Genomics of Obligate (and Nonobligate) Biotrophs. Annu Rev Phytopathol. 2012;50:91–109." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR71" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2564">71</a>], including the ectomycorrhizal ascomycetes <i>T. melanosporum</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 58" title="Martin F, Kohler A, Murat C, Balestrini R, Coutinho PM, Jaillon O, Montanini B, Morin E, Noel B, Percudani R, et al. Perigord black truffle genome uncovers evolutionary origins and mechanisms of symbiosis. Nature. 2010;464(7291):1033–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR58" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2570">58</a>], <i>E. granulatus</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 72" title="Quandt CA, Kohler A, Hesse CN, Sharpton TJ, Martin F, Spatafora JW. Metagenome sequence of Elaphomyces granulatus from sporocarp tissue reveals Ascomycota ectomycorrhizal fingerprints of genome expansion and a Proteobacteria-rich microbiome. Environ Microbiol. 2015;17(8):2952–68." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR72" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2576">72</a>], and <i>C. geophilum</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 73" title="Peter M, Kohler A, Ohm RA, Kuo A, Krutzmann J, Morin E, Arend M, Barry KW, Binder M, Choi C, et al. Ectomycorrhizal ecology is imprinted in the genome of the dominant symbiotic fungus Cenococcum geophilum. Nat Commun. 2016;7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR73" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2583">73</a>] but this was not observed in <i>C. grayi</i> (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig2">2</a>). Like other Chlorophyta, <i>A. glomerata</i> has more and larger introns than fungi. Its genome (56 Mb and 10,000 gene models) is significantly smaller than that of <i>C. reinhardtii</i> (120 Mb) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 49" title="Merchant SS, Prochnik SE, Vallon O, Harris EH, Karpowicz SJ, Witman GB, Terry A, Salamov A, Fritz-Laylin LK, Marechal-Drouard L, et al. The Chlamydomonas genome reveals the evolution of key animal and plant functions. Science. 2007;318(5848):245–51." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR49" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2598">49</a>] but is larger than that of other Trebouxiophyceae like <i>C. subellipsoideae</i> C-169 (49 Mb) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 54" title="Blanc G, Agarkova I, Grimwood J, Kuo A, Brueggeman A, Dunigan DD, Gurnon J, Ladunga I, Lindquist E, Lucas S, et al. The genome of the polar eukaryotic microalga Coccomyxa subellipsoidea reveals traits of cold adaptation. Genome Biol. 2012;13(5):R39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR54" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2605">54</a>] and <i>C. variabilis</i> NC64A (46.2 Mb) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 50" title="Blanc G, Duncan G, Agarkova I, Borodovsky M, Gurnon J, Kuo A, Lindquist E, Lucas S, Pangilinan J, Polle J, et al. The Chlorella variabilis NC64A Genome Reveals Adaptation to Photosymbiosis, Coevolution with Viruses, and Cryptic Sex. Plant Cell. 2010;22(9):2943–55." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR50" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2611">50</a>] (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig2">2</a>). <i>C. subellipsoideae</i> C-169 is free-living, but the genus includes lichenized species [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 56" title="Zoller S, Lutzoni F. Slow algae, fast fungi: exceptionally high nucleotide substitution rate differences between lichenized fungi Omphalina and their symbiotic green algae Coccomyxa. Mol Phylogenet Evol. 2003;29(3):629–40." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR56" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2621">56</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 74" title="Lohtander K, Oksanen I, Rikkinen J. Genetic diversity of green algal and cyanobacterial photobionts in Nephroma (Peltigerales). Lichenologist. 2003;35:325–39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR74" id="ref-link-section-d4765e2624">74</a>]. <i>Chlorella</i> NC64A is a facultative symbiont of ciliates and is host to large dsDNA viruses. Our analyses suggest that <i>A. glomerata</i> has also been host to large DNA viruses (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec5">A low-GC region in Asterochloris is a remnant of a large virus insertion, an HGT-mediator</a> section), although a live virus has not yet been isolated from it. Over evolutionary time, chromosomal rearrangements left little synteny among the genomes of <i>A. glomerata</i>, <i>Coccomyxa</i> C-169 and <i>Chlorella</i> NC64A (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM2">2</a>).</p><div class="c-article-table" data-test="inline-table" data-container-section="table" id="table-1"><figure><figcaption class="c-article-table__figcaption"><b id="Tab1" data-test="table-caption">Table 1 Genome Basics</b></figcaption><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="table-link" data-track="click" data-track-action="view table" data-track-label="button" rel="nofollow" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/tables/1"><span>Full size table</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-2" data-title="Fig. 2"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig2" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 2</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/2" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig2_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-2-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig2_HTML.png" alt="figure2" loading="lazy" width="685" height="1030"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-2-desc"><p>Phylogenies, genome sizes and sequence distribution. <i>Left side</i>: Fungal (top) and algal (bottom) PhyML trees (LG + G + F + I) for <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> involving, respectively, a random sample of 6000 and 4000 ungapped sites extracted from a concatenated alignment of 2137 and 683 orthologous protein families containing 794,828 and 159,356 ungapped sites. Bootstrap support values label internodes. Scales indicate nucleotide substitutions per site. <i>Right side</i>: Bars are proportional to genome size, and different shadings indicate the proportions of recent and older sequence replicas or of unique sequences. Duplicated sequences in genomes were revealed by BLAST alignment of the genomic sequence against itself at the nucleotide (BLASTN) or amino acid (TBLASTX) levels. The duplicated regions include regular genes as well as repeated elements (not yet fully characterized), but microsatellites and low complexity sequences were filtered out. Sequences that matched in both BLASTN and TBLASTX searches were only counted in the BLASTN category. Only alignments with e-values &lt;1e<sup>− 15</sup> in both the BLASTN and TBLASTX analyses were considered</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/2" data-track-dest="link:Figure2 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM3">3</a> shows a KEGG-based categorization of the mycobiont and photobiont gene models. In this broad overview only the environmental information processing category (signal transduction) appears overrepresented in both symbiotic partners. Among the free-living <i>Aspergillus</i> species, from the closely related class Eurotiomycetes (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig2">2</a>), the signal transduction genes constitute between 1.4 and 1.84% of the annotated genes [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 75" title="Arnaud MB, Cerqueira GC, Inglis DO, Skrzypek MS, Binkley J, Chibucos MC, Crabtree J, Howarth C, Orvis J, Shah P, et al. The Aspergillus Genome Database (AspGD): recent developments in comprehensive multispecies curation, comparative genomics and community resources. Nucleic Acids Res. 2012;40(D1):D653–9." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR75" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3042">75</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 76" title="
                           Aspergillus Genome Database. 
                    http://www.aspgd.org/
                    
                  ." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR76" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3045">76</a>], while in <i>C. grayi</i> the proportion is 6.2%. In <i>A. glomerata</i> the proportion of signal transduction genes is 7.8%, while among other Chlorophyta they represent 5–6% of the total [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 77" title="Molnar I, Lopez D, Wisecaver JH, Devarenne TP, Weiss TL, Pellegrini M, Hackett JD. Bio-crude transcriptomics: gene discovery and metabolic network reconstruction for the biosynthesis of the terpenome of the hydrocarbon oil-producing green alga, Botryococcus braunii race B (Showa).
