Bmc Genomics. 2012;13:576." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR77" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3055">77</a>]. These broad comparisons are only suggestive of an expansion of signal transduction components in the <i>C. grayi</i> partners because methodologies and annotations differ. A specific analysis of signal transduction functions (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec15">Specific survey of mycobiont and photobiont signal transduction components</a> section) also reveals diversification in some of the <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> components. This bilateral restructuring may underpin the multifaceted interactions between partners [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 10" title="Honegger R. The symbiotic phenotype of lichen-forming ascomycetes and their endo- and epibionts. In: Hock B, editor. Fungal Associations, vol. 9. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer; 2012. p. 287–339. ISBN 978-3-642-30825-3." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR10" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3071">10</a>].</p><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec5">A low-GC region in <i>Asterochloris</i> is a remnant of a large virus insertion, an HGT-mediator</h4><p>In 98% of the <i>Asterochloris</i> nuclear genome the GC content is between 56 and 62%. However, it is significantly lower (49%) in two large genomic regions, each located at one end of two scaffolds (~ 441 Kb on scaffold 80 and ~ 102 Kb on scaffold 120). Each low-GC region reaches the scaffold’s extremity with an array of duplicated 141-bp sequence units (totaling 1300 bp on scaffold 80 and 2053 bp on scaffold 120). These repeated sequences are found nowhere else in the <i>Asterochloris</i> genome. Figure&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig3">3</a>a has the two scaffolds joined at the repeats, forming a single low-GC contiguous chromosomal region. Genomic contiguity has been confirmed by PCR and sequencing across the junction (Armaleo, not shown). The joined low-GC regions contain 462 predicted protein coding genes (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM4">4</a>), 236 of which exhibit significant matches in GenBank (BLASTP e-value &lt;1e<sup>− 5</sup>). Of these, 45% have their best match in double-stranded DNA viruses [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 78" title="Iyer LA, Balaji S, Koonin EV, Aravind L. Evolutionary genomics of nucleo-cytoplasmic large DNA viruses. Virus Res. 2006;117(1):156–84." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR78" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3101">78</a>]. While most genes in the algal genome have many introns, only 36 of the 462 protein coding genes in this region are predicted to have them, and only 24 of 462 (5.2%) match chlorophyte genes. This differs markedly from the rest of the genome (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig3">3</a>b), where most genes have best matches in chlorophytes (69%). The sharp switch in nucleotide composition and phylogenetic affinity strongly suggest that the low-GC region is a remnant of a large integrated viral genome, about 540 kb long. Nucleo-cytoplasmic large DNA viruses (NCLDV) form a monophyletic class of viruses that infect a variety of eukaryotes [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 78" title="Iyer LA, Balaji S, Koonin EV, Aravind L. Evolutionary genomics of nucleo-cytoplasmic large DNA viruses. Virus Res. 2006;117(1):156–84." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR78" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3107">78</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 79" title="Iyer LM, Aravind L, Koonin EV. Common origin of four diverse families of large eukaryotic DNA viruses. J Virol. 2001;75(23):11720–34." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR79" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3110">79</a>], including other algae and protists [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Cock JM, Sterck L, Rouze P, Scornet D, Allen AE, Amoutzias G, Anthouard V, Artiguenave F, Aury JM, Badger JH, et al. The Ectocarpus genome and the independent evolution of multicellularity in brown algae. Nature. 2010;465(7298):617–21." href="#ref-CR80" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3113">80</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Blanc G, Gallot-Lavallee L, Maumus F. Provirophages in the Bigelowiella genome bear testimony to past encounters with giant viruses. P Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2015;112(38):E5318–26." href="#ref-CR81" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3113_1">81</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 82" title="Maumus F, Blanc G. Study of Gene Trafficking between Acanthamoeba and Giant Viruses Suggests an Undiscovered Family of Amoeba-Infecting Viruses. Genome Biol Evol. 2016;8(11):3351–63." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR82" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3116">82</a>]. A phylogenetic analysis places the <i>Asterochloris</i> virus within the <i>Phycodnaviridae</i> family, sister to viruses that infect other green algae (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM4">4</a>). The genome of the <i>A. glomerata</i> virus may be the largest among alga-infecting NCLDVs sequenced to date (ranging from 154 Kb for a <i>Feldmannia</i> sp. virus [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 83" title="Schroeder DC, Park Y, Yoon HM, Lee YS, Kang W, Meints RH, Ivey RG, Choi TJ. Genomic analysis of the smallest giant virus - Feldmannia sp virus 158. Virology. 2009;384(1):223–32." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR83" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3135">83</a>] to 473 Kb for a <i>Chrysochromulina ericina</i> virus [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 84" title="Gallot-Lavallee L, Blanc G, Claverie JM. Comparative Genomics of Chrysochromulina Ericina Virus and Other Microalga-Infecting Large DNA Viruses Highlights Their Intricate Evolutionary Relationship with the Established Mimiviridae Family. J Virol. 2017;91(14)." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR84" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3142">84</a>]). Viral DNA thus is a major vehicle of HGT in <i>A. glomerata</i> and other algae [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 85" title="Gallot-Lavallee L, Blanc G. A Glimpse of Nucleo-Cytoplasmic Large DNA Virus Biodiversity through the Eukaryotic GenomicsWindow. Viruses. 2017;9(1):17–31." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR85" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3148">85</a>]. The significance of this group of virally transferred genes for the symbiosis is unclear at this time. However, some of the genes in the viral region are actively transcribed, which suggests that they may eventually become functional in the photobiont. Other genes with potential symbiotic significance have been introduced into trebouxioid algae probably by HGT from bacteria [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 44" title="Carniel FC, Gerdol M, Montagner A, Banchi E, De Moro G, Manfrin C, Muggia L, Pallavicini A, Tretiach M. New features of desiccation tolerance in the lichen photobiont Trebouxia gelatinosa are revealed by a transcriptomic approach. Plant Mol Biol. 2016;91(3):319–39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR44" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3151">44</a>] and archaea (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec14">Photobiont expanded families</a> section). Trebouxioid algae ancestors may have even acquired genes from fungi before the origins of lichens [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 86" title="Beck A, Divakar PK, Zhang N, Molina MC, Struwe L. Evidence of ancient horizontal gene transfer between fungi and the terrestrial alga Trebouxia. Org Divers Evol. 2015;15(2):235–48." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR86" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3158">86</a>].</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-3" data-title="Fig. 3"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig3" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 3</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/3" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig3_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-3-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig3_HTML.png" alt="figure3" loading="lazy" width="685" height="750"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-3-desc"><p>A viral insertion in the <i>Asterochloris</i> genome. <b>a</b> GC content and gene distribution. The diagram represents a 1 Mb genomic region produced by joining scaffolds 120 and 80 at their inverted repeat-containing edges (purple triangles). The % GC content is proportional to the height and color intensity of the orange-yellow band. Genes are indicated by rectangles whose color represents the category of their best match in Genbank (BLASTP e-value &lt;1e<sup>− 5</sup>). The blue or red segments perpendicular to the Kb line are repeated sequences or gaps, respectively. The low GC region in yellow represents the remnant of a viral insertion (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM4">4</a>). <b>b</b> Origins of best matches. Most genes in the low GC region of <i>A. glomerata</i> are viral or prokaryotic in origin, in contrast to those in the genome as a whole</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/3" data-track-dest="link:Figure3 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec6">Heterothallism probably evolved from homothallism in <i>Cladonia</i>; genetic evidence for sex in <i>Asterochloris</i>
                           </h4><p>Typically in ascomycetes, two kinds of mating genes, <i>MAT1–1</i> and <i>MAT1–2</i>, cooperate in mating [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 87" title="Dyer PS, Inderbitzin P, Debuchy R. Mating-Type Structure, Function, Regulation and Evolution in the Pezizomycotina. Mycota. 2016;1:351–85." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR87" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3218">87</a>]. They are referred to as idiomorphs because, while they share the same locus, <i>MAT1</i>, their encoded proteins are different transcription factors: <i>MAT1–1</i> is characterized by an α1-domain [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 88" title="Martin T, Lu SW, van Tilbeurgh H, Ripoll DR, Dixelius C, Turgeon BG, Debuchy R. Tracing the Origin of the Fungal alpha 1 Domain Places Its Ancestor in the HMG-Box Superfamily: Implication for Fungal Mating-Type Evolution. Plos One. 2010;5(12)." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR88" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3228">88</a>] and <i>MAT1–2</i> by a MAT A_ HMG domain [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 88" title="Martin T, Lu SW, van Tilbeurgh H, Ripoll DR, Dixelius C, Turgeon BG, Debuchy R. Tracing the Origin of the Fungal alpha 1 Domain Places Its Ancestor in the HMG-Box Superfamily: Implication for Fungal Mating-Type Evolution. Plos One. 2010;5(12)." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR88" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3234">88</a>]. These may be linked also to other idiomorph-specific genes. When both <i>MAT1–1</i> and <i>MAT1–2</i> are in the same genome, the fungus is self-fertile (homothallic), but when a genome contains only <i>MAT1–1</i> or only <i>MAT1–2</i>, the fungus is self-sterile (heterothallic) and mating occurs only between different mating types; both heterothallic and homothallic species of lichen fungi have been found [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Murtagh GJ, Dyer PS, Crittenden PD. Reproductive systems - Sex and the single lichen. Nature. 2000;404(6778):564." href="#ref-CR89" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3250">89</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Scherrer S, Zippler U, Honegger R. Characterisation of the mating-type locus in the genus Xanthoria (lichen-forming ascomycetes, lecanoromycetes). Fungal Genet Biol. 2005;42(12):976–88." href="#ref-CR90" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3250_1">90</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Seymour FA, Crittenden PD, Dickinson MJ, Paoletti M, Montiel D, Cho L, Dyer PS. Breeding systems in the lichen-forming fungal genus Cladonia. Fungal Genet Biol. 2005;42(6):554–63." href="#ref-CR91" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3250_2">91</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Singh G, Dal Grande F, Cornejo C, Schmitt I, Scheidegger C. Genetic Basis of Self-Incompatibility in the Lichen-Forming Fungus Lobaria pulmonaria and Skewed Frequency Distribution of Mating-Type Idiomorphs: Implications for Conservation. Plos One. 2012;7(12)." href="#ref-CR92" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3250_3">92</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 93" title="Pizarro D, Divakar PK, Crespo AM, Pozo GG. Genome-wide search, characterization and comparison of MAT gene families in lichen-forming fungi. In:  8th International Association for Lichenology Symposium: 2016. Helsinki: University of Helsinki; 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR93" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3253">93</a>]. <i>C. grayi</i> produces typical ascomycetous fruiting bodies with apothecia (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig1">1</a>); the <i>MAT</i> locus in the single-spore isolate <i>Cgr/DA2myc/ss</i>, like in many Pezizomycota [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 87" title="Dyer PS, Inderbitzin P, Debuchy R. Mating-Type Structure, Function, Regulation and Evolution in the Pezizomycotina. Mycota. 2016;1:351–85." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR87" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3269">87</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 94" title="Rydholm C, Dyer PS, Lutzoni F. DNA sequence characterization and molecular evolution of MAT1 and MAT2 mating-type loci of the self-compatible ascomycete mold Neosartorya fischeri. Eukaryot Cell. 2007;6(5):868–74." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR94" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3272">94</a>], is located between <i>Apn2</i> and <i>Sla2</i>, genes for a nuclease and a cytoskeleton assembly protein, respectively (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig4">4</a>a). The locus in <i>Cgr/DA2myc/ss</i> contains the core gene <i>MAT1–1</i> and an associated gene [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 87" title="Dyer PS, Inderbitzin P, Debuchy R. Mating-Type Structure, Function, Regulation and Evolution in the Pezizomycotina. Mycota. 2016;1:351–85." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR87" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3291">87</a>], <i>MAT1–1-7</i>, but no <i>MAT1–2</i> (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a> and Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig4">4</a>a), as do the sequenced mating-type loci of single-spore isolates from two other <i>Cladonia</i> species (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a>). This expands earlier RAPD-PCR and RFLP data on three other <i>Cladonia</i> species, also heterothallic [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 91" title="Seymour FA, Crittenden PD, Dickinson MJ, Paoletti M, Montiel D, Cho L, Dyer PS. Breeding systems in the lichen-forming fungal genus Cladonia. Fungal Genet Biol. 2005;42(6):554–63." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR91" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3316">91</a>]. PCR amplification and sequencing of the region between <i>Sla2</i> and <i>Apn2</i> from DNA of a natural <i>C. grayi</i> thallus revealed a single <i>MAT1–2</i> gene (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a> and Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig4">4</a>a; sequence accession MH795990), further supporting heterothallism. The sequences of the two loci revealed the presence of vestigial sequences suggesting that, in <i>Cladonia</i>, heterothallism might have evolved from homothallism (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a> and Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig4">4</a>b). This appears to diverge from the trends in other ascomycete genera where homothallism is thought to have evolved from heterothallism [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Rydholm C, Dyer PS, Lutzoni F. DNA sequence characterization and molecular evolution of MAT1 and MAT2 mating-type loci of the self-compatible ascomycete mold Neosartorya fischeri. Eukaryot Cell. 2007;6(5):868–74." href="#ref-CR94" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3348">94</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Coppin E, Debuchy R, Arnaise S, Picard M. Mating types and sexual development in filamentous ascomycetes. Microbiol Mol Biol R. 1997;61(4):411–28." href="#ref-CR95" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3348_1">95</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 96" title="Yun SH, Berbee ML, Yoder OC, Turgeon BG. Evolution of the fungal self-fertile reproductive life style from self-sterile ancestors. P Natl Acad Sci U S A. 1999;96(10):5592–7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR96" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3351">96</a>], although not in all cases [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 97" title="Lee SC, Ni M, Li WJ, Shertz C, Heitman J. The Evolution of Sex: a Perspective from the Fungal Kingdom. Microbiol Mol Biol R. 2010;74(2):298–340." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR97" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3354">97</a>].</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-4" data-title="Fig. 4"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig4" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 4</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/4" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig4_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-4-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig4_HTML.png" alt="figure4" loading="lazy" width="685" height="710"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-4-desc"><p><i>Cladonia</i> MAT loci and their evolution. <b>a</b> Configurations of the MAT loci in three <i>Cladonia</i> species. The top diagrammed alignment is based on the alignment between the annotated <i>C. grayi MAT1–1</i> region (scaffold_00075:76000–90,000 at [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 67" title="Institute DJG. Cladonia grayi Cgr/DA2myc/ss v2.0. Available from: 
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Clagr3/Clagr3.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 8 Aug 2018." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR67" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3378">67</a>]) and a provisional sequence of the <i>C. grayi MAT1–2</i> region (accession MH795990). The <i>C. grayi MAT1–1</i> and <i>MAT1–2</i> regions are drawn above the basepair indicator line. Under the line are the <i>MAT1–1</i> regions derived from the genomes of two other <i>Cladonia</i> species (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a>). In <i>C. grayi</i>, the conserved flanking regions are gray, while the unrelated central regions are stippled differently for each mating type. Dark or gray arrows represent genes and gene-segments. CLAGR_008123-RA is considered a putative <i>MAT1–1-7</i> ortholog because of its location and its BLAST hits to <i>MAT1–1-7</i> orthologs from <i>Trichophyton</i> and other fungi. <b>b</b> Evolutionary model. Horizontal colored arrows represent <i>MAT</i> idiomorphs. The central line represents the MAT locus configuration of a possible homothallic <i>Cladonia</i> ancestor, and the vertical arrows represent the putative transitions towards the present heterothallic <i>MAT1–1</i> (orange) or <i>MAT1–2</i> (blue) configurations (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a>). The graded shading in the deletion triangle leading to <i>MAT1–2</i> symbolizes the deletion’s undefined left boundary beyond <i>MAT1–1-7</i></p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/4" data-track-dest="link:Figure4 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>Sexual reproduction is generally assumed not to occur in trebouxoid algae like <i>Asterochloris</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 98" title="Lewis LA, McCourt RM. Green algae and the origin of land plants. Am J Bot. 2004;91(10):1535–56." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR98" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3451">98</a>]. They reproduce vegetatively, both in the lichen thallus or in culture, through non-motile autospores and aplanospores or through flagellated zoospores [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 99" title="Skaloud P, Steinova J, Ridka T, Vancurova L, Peksa O. Assembling the Challenging Puzzle of Algal Biodiversity: Species Delimitation within the Genus Asterochloris (Trebouxiophyceae, Chlorophyta). J Phycol. 2015;51(3):507–27." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR99" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3454">99</a>]. Law and Lewis proposed that sexual reproduction in the photobiont, the inhabitant in the mutualism, should be selected against [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 100" title="Law R, Lewis DH. Biotic Environments and the Maintenance of Sex - Some Evidence from Mutualistic Symbioses. Biol J Linn Soc. 1983;20(3):249–76." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR100" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3457">100</a>]. However, the occurrence of sex in these algae is indicated by isolated microscopic observation of presumptive gametes in the 1920s [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 99" title="Skaloud P, Steinova J, Ridka T, Vancurova L, Peksa O. Assembling the Challenging Puzzle of Algal Biodiversity: Species Delimitation within the Genus Asterochloris (Trebouxiophyceae, Chlorophyta). J Phycol. 2015;51(3):507–27." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR99" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3460">99</a>], 1960s (figure 28 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 101" title="Ahmadjian V. Some New and Interesting Species of Trebouxia, a Genus of Lichenized Algae. American J Bot. 1960;47(8):677–83." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR101" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3464">101</a>]; page 135 and figure 28 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 102" title="Ahmadjian V. A Guide to the Algae Occurring as Lichen Symbionts: Isolation, Culture, Cultural Physiology, and Identification. Phycologia. 1967;6(2/3):127–60." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR102" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3467">102</a>]) and in 2015 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 99" title="Skaloud P, Steinova J, Ridka T, Vancurova L, Peksa O. Assembling the Challenging Puzzle of Algal Biodiversity: Species Delimitation within the Genus Asterochloris (Trebouxiophyceae, Chlorophyta). J Phycol. 2015;51(3):507–27." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR99" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3470">99</a>], and molecular evidence of genetic recombination was also uncovered through phylogenetic analysis of a <i>Trebouxia</i> population in <i>Letharia</i> lichens [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 103" title="Kroken S, Taylor JW. Phylogenetic species, reproductive mode, and specificity of the green alga Trebouxia forming lichens with the fungal genus Letharia. Bryologist. 2000;103(4):645–60." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR103" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3479">103</a>]. The identification of many meiotic genes in the <i>A. glomerata</i> genome and their expression in coculture (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a>) add further evidence for the occurrence of meiosis in trebouxoid algae, probably in their free-living stages [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 29" title="Sanders WB. Observing microscopic phases of lichen life cycles on transparent substrata placed in situ. Lichenologist. 2005;37:373–82." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR29" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3489">29</a>]. The gametes observed in <i>Asterochloris</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 99" title="Skaloud P, Steinova J, Ridka T, Vancurova L, Peksa O. Assembling the Challenging Puzzle of Algal Biodiversity: Species Delimitation within the Genus Asterochloris (Trebouxiophyceae, Chlorophyta). J Phycol. 2015;51(3):507–27." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR99" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3495">99</a>] are flagellated, as are its vegetative zoospores (9 + 2 type [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 104" title="Slocum RD, Ahmadjian V, Hildreth KC. Zoosporogenesis in Trebouxia Gelatinosa - Ultrastructure Potential for Zoospore Release and Implications for the Lichen Association. Lichenologist. 1980;12:173–87." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR104" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3498">104</a>]). Not surprisingly, the motility proteins present in <i>Asterochloris</i> match those of other flagellated chlorophytes but are mostly absent from non-motile chlorophytes (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig5">5</a> and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a>). The critical implications of fungal and algal sexual reproduction for the lichen symbiosis and for symbiont autonomy are discussed in Conclusions.</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-5" data-title="Fig. 5"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig5" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 5</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/5" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig5_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-5-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig5_HTML.png" alt="figure5" loading="lazy" width="685" height="816"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-5-desc"><p>Flagellar proteins. <b>a</b> Number of candidate flagella proteins in chlorophytes. Reference <i>C. reinhardtii</i> proteins of the CiliaCut protein set (blue bars) and flagella proteome (green bars) were searched for putative orthologs in sequenced motile and non-motile chlorophytes using the reciprocal best BLASTP hit criterion. <b>b</b> The 314 candidate <i>A. glomerata</i> flagella proteins identified from multiple sources of evidence (see Methods). <b>c</b> Distribution of flagella proteins across Chlorophytes. The left cladogram shows the likely evolutionary relationships of sequenced Chlorophytes. The ƒ mark indicates organisms known to build motile flagella. Crei: <i>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii</i>; Volvox: <i>Volvox carteri</i>; C169: <i>Coccomyxa subellipsoidea</i> C-169; NC64A: <i>Chlorella variabilis</i> NC64A; Otau: <i>Ostreococcus tauri</i>; Oluc: <i>Ostreococcus lucimarinus</i>; M. CCMP: <i>Micromonas pusilla CCMP1545</i>; M. RCC: <i>Micromonas</i> sp. RC299. Presence (dot) or absence (circle) of putative orthologs identified by reciprocal best BLASTP hit of <i>C. reinhardtii</i> outer dynein proteins, inner dynein proteins, radial spoke proteins, central pair proteins and intraflagellar transport proteins</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/5" data-track-dest="link:Figure5 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec7">Search for symbiosis-specific genes I: differential expression in coculture vs. monoculture</h3><p>Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Tab2">2</a> lists the genes discussed in the next three sections. The system to survey the gene sets differentially transcribed when fungus and alga first contact each other is based on three parallel cultures on filters placed on low nutrient agar medium [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 33" title="Joneson S, Armaleo D, Lutzoni F. Fungal and algal gene expression in early developmental stages of lichen-symbiosis. Mycologia. 2011;103(2):291–306." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR33" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3585">33</a>]: the aposymbiotic fungus, the aposymbiotic alga, and a coculture of the two (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig6">6</a> and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>). RNA was extracted from the individual cultures after 21 days of growth on the filters. Differential expression data (Methods) were analyzed in two ways. In the first, we identified GO annotations and metabolic pathways significantly enriched among genes induced or repressed more than 1.5x (0.6 &gt; log<sub>2</sub> &gt; − 0.6) in coculture relative to monoculture. In the second, a more extensive approach, we focused only on induced genes and added information from PFAM domains and literature searches to define each gene’s putative function in more detail than was possible through GO terms alone.</p><div class="c-article-table" data-test="inline-table" data-container-section="table" id="table-2"><figure><figcaption class="c-article-table__figcaption"><b id="Tab2" data-test="table-caption">Table 2 Compilation of genes/proteins of potential symbiotic significance discussed in Search for symbiosis-specific genes I, II, and III sections</b></figcaption><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="table-link" data-track="click" data-track-action="view table" data-track-label="button" rel="nofollow" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/tables/2"><span>Full size table</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-6" data-title="Fig. 6"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig6" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 6</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/6" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig6_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-6-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig6_HTML.png" alt="figure6" loading="lazy" width="685" height="310"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-6-desc"><p>Cultures of <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> reconstituted on filters in Petri dishes</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/6" data-track-dest="link:Figure6 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec8">GO term-centered analysis of transcription in coculture</h4><p>The limited results are listed in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>. In coculture, the alga shows only differential activation of ubiquitin-dependent catabolic processes. The fungus induces redox-active enzymes and proteases, a finding also reflected in the data from the more extensive approach. Surprisingly, however, in presence of the alga the fungus also down-regulates several genes involved in respiratory ATP generation; the biological significance of this remains to be determined, pending experimental confirmation.</p><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec9">Extended analysis of transcription induced in coculture</h4><p>In this analysis we used day-21 ratios of coculture (Co) vs. monoculture (Mo) RPKM directly rather than the log<sub>2</sub> values. Ratios are abbreviated here as Co/Mo. In each symbiont, a few hundred genes changed expression in coculture relative to monoculture, while most genes remained unaffected (Co/Mo <span class="stix">≅</span> 1) (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig7">7</a>). The extended transcription analysis was limited to the genes induced in coculture. Due to differences in Co/Mo ranges for the symbionts (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>), we defined two different Co/Mo induction thresholds: ≥ 2 for the fungus, ≥1.3 for the alga (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig7">7</a>). This yielded 795 up-regulated genes out of 11,388 in <i>C. grayi</i> (7%) and 471 out of 10,024 in <i>A. glomerata</i> (4.7%) (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>). Induced gene products were inferred by BLAST [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 105" title="Altschul SF, Madden TL, Schaffer AA, Zhang J, Zhang Z, Miller W, Lipman DJ. Gapped BLAST and PSI-BLAST: a new generation of protein database search programs. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997;25(17):3389–402." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR105" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3893">105</a>] and, based on GO terms, PFAM domains and literature searches, were grouped into three categories summarized in Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig8">8</a>: unknown and unique to each symbiont, insufficiently defined, and better defined (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>).</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-7" data-title="Fig. 7"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig7" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 7</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/7" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig7_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-7-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig7_HTML.png" alt="figure7" loading="lazy" width="685" height="383"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-7-desc"><p>Differential fungal (<i>C. grayi</i>) and algal (<i>A. glomerata</i>) gene expression in coculture vs. monoculture. RPKM expression ratios are sorted from high to low. Genes considered unaffected in coculture are labeled gray (Co/Mo ~ 1). Those labeled black above or below the gray range are considered induced or repressed, respectively. Induction and repression thresholds correspond respectively to 2 and 0.5 for the fungus and 1.3 and 0.77 for the alga. Notice the smaller range of differential expression induction displayed by the alga under our experimental conditions (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>)</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/7" data-track-dest="link:Figure7 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-8" data-title="Fig. 8"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig8" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 8</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/8" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig8_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-8-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig8_HTML.png" alt="figure8" loading="lazy" width="685" height="229"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-8-desc"><p>Classes of genes differentially induced during early fungus-alga interactions in coculture. The pie charts divide the induced genes for each symbiont into three broad classes (numbers of genes in parentheses). The “better defined” genes are subdivided in groups roughly comparable between the symbionts (gray and white boxes). The area of each box is proportional to the percent of genes it contains relative to all better defined genes (265 for the fungus and 243 for the alga). The number behind each group’s name indicates its enrichment factor relative to the whole genome (see Methods). The hatched areas represent groups with less than 10 genes each. The <i>p</i> values for the enrichment of the indicated groups within the induced genes are all &lt; 0.05, and most are &lt;&lt; 10<sup>− 3</sup></p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/8" data-track-dest="link:Figure8 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>Relative to their overall genomic frequency of 7.2% (821/11388), mycobiont secreted proteins are disproportionately enriched to 18.5% (147/795) in coculture (<i>p</i> = 2.8E-28). The genomic average protein length is 477 AA, while the induced and secreted proteins are smaller, averaging 341 AA (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig9">9</a> and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>), with most unknown and unique to <i>C. grayi</i>. The smallest proteins tend to be also among the most strongly induced. <i>Cladonia</i> shares biotrophic overexpression of small secreted proteins with the mycorrhizal basidiomycete <i>Laccaria bicolor</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 57" title="Martin F, Aerts A, Ahren D, Brun A, Danchin EGJ, Duchaussoy F, Gibon J, Kohler A, Lindquist E, Pereda V, et al. The genome of Laccaria bicolor provides insights into mycorrhizal symbiosis. Nature. 2008;452(7183):88–U87." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR57" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3974">57</a>], the mycorrhizal ascomycete <i>Tuber melanosporum</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 58" title="Martin F, Kohler A, Murat C, Balestrini R, Coutinho PM, Jaillon O, Montanini B, Morin E, Noel B, Percudani R, et al. Perigord black truffle genome uncovers evolutionary origins and mechanisms of symbiosis. Nature. 2010;464(7291):1033–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR58" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3980">58</a>], and with pathogenic fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 106" title="Ellis JG, Rafiqi M, Gan P, Chakrabarti A, Dodds PN. Recent progress in discovery and functional analysis of effector proteins of fungal and oomycete plant pathogens. Curr Opin Plant Biol. 2009;12(4):399–405." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR106" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3983">106</a>]. The <i>Cladonia</i> secretome (821 proteins) is comparable in size to the secretomes of ectomycorrhizal and many other fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 107" title="Pellegrin C, Morin E, Martin FM, Veneault-Fourrey C. Comparative Analysis of Secretomes from Ectomycorrhizal Fungi with an Emphasis on Small-Secreted Proteins. Front Microbiol. 2015;6:1278." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR107" id="ref-link-section-d4765e3990">107</a>]. Also in the alga, relative to their overall genomic frequency of 3.6% (365/10025), secreted proteins appear significantly enriched (<i>p</i> = 0.00003) among the 471 induced proteins (32/471&nbsp;=&nbsp;6.8%), but they are not significantly smaller than average (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig9">9</a> and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>). It remains to be seen whether the algal secretome in early symbiosis shares any features with the secretion responses of higher plants to fungal infection [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 108" title="Kim ST, Kang YH, Wang YM, Wu JN, Park ZY, Rakwal R, KumarAgrawal G, Lee SY, Kang KY. Secretome analysis of differentially induced proteins in rice suspension-cultured cells triggered by rice blast fungus and elicitor. Proteomics. 2009;9(5):1302–13." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR108" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4002">108</a>].</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-9" data-title="Fig. 9"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig9" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 9</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/9" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig9_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-9-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig9_HTML.png" alt="figure9" loading="lazy" width="685" height="312"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-9-desc"><p>Secreted proteins among the proteins induced in coculture. The small black symbols coalescing into a curve represent the Co/Mo ratios of the genes induced in coculture; the circles represent the corresponding protein sizes, gray for non-secreted, black for secreted proteins. The average sizes (# of amino acids) of a) all genome proteins, b) all induced proteins, c) all induced and secreted proteins are a) 477, b) 381, c) 341 for the fungus and a) 447, b) 420, c) 436 for the alga. Proteins were considered secreted only if they scored as such in all three programs SignalP [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 109" title="Petersen TN, Brunak S, von Heijne G, Nielsen H. SignalP 4.0: discriminating signal peptides from transmembrane regions. Nat Methods. 2011;8(10):785–6." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR109" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4015">109</a>], TargetP [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 110" title="Emanuelsson O, Brunak S, von Heijne G, Nielsen H. Locating proteins in the cell using TargetP, SignalP and related tools. Nat Protoc. 2007;2(4):953–71." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR110" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4018">110</a>], and TMHMM [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 111" title="Krogh A, Larsson B, von Heijne G, Sonnhammer ELL. Predicting transmembrane protein topology with a hidden Markov model: Application to complete genomes. J Mol Biol. 2001;305(3):567–80." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR111" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4021">111</a>]. In TMHMM, a transmembrane domain prediction program, a protein was considered compatible with secretion only if it had either no predicted TM domains or only one at the N terminus. The data used in this figure are in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a></p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/9" data-track-dest="link:Figure9 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>The better-defined gene products induced in coculture, 265 in <i>C. grayi</i> and 243 in <i>A. glomerata</i>, were subdivided for enrichment analysis in broad functional subgroups of at least 10 genes each (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig8">8</a>, Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>). Except for the limited enrichment (1.4-fold) of signal transduction and defense genes in the fungus, most subgroups in both symbionts were enriched between 2- and 9-fold and with high significance in the set of induced genes relative to the whole genome (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig8">8</a>). At these early stages, both partners respond to the other’s presence by activating transcription, cell wall metabolism and protein turnover. The mycobiont’s specific responses center on upregulating membrane transporters, secreted hydrolases, and small proteins, broadly resembling the symbiotic responses of the EM fungus <i>L. bicolor</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 112" title="Martin F, Nehls U. Harnessing ectomycorrhizal genomics for ecological insights. Curr Opin Plant Biol. 2009;12(4):508–15." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR112" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4056">112</a>]. The photobiont’s specific responses center on growth and motility through the predominant activation of DNA and signal transduction processes, as well as protein trafficking and zoospore formation (flagella). This correlates with the alga’s rapid initial growth visible in coculture compared to monoculture (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>), possibly reflecting the growth observed in nature in free-living trebouxoid algae near suitable fungal hyphae [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 29" title="Sanders WB. Observing microscopic phases of lichen life cycles on transparent substrata placed in situ. Lichenologist. 2005;37:373–82." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR29" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4062">29</a>] and increasing the chances of successful formation of new lichen initials. This issue is taken up again in Conclusions, where the importance for lichen evolution of re-lichenization of free-living algae released from natural thalli is discussed. It needs underlining that this coculture system and similar ones [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 113" title="Athukorala SNP, Piercey-Normore MD. Recognition- and defense-related gene expression at 3 resynthesis stages in lichen symbionts. Can J Microbiol. 2015;61(1):1–12." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR113" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4065">113</a>] do not proceed beyond formation of poorly differentiated lichenoids (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>), and thus they do not capture the complete interaction network extended in space and time needed for proper lichenization in nature. Individual genes of potential symbiotic significance are discussed in <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec10">Inferences from differential transcription about nutritional fluxes at the symbiotic interface</a> section and in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>.</p><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec10">Inferences from differential transcription about nutritional fluxes at the symbiotic interface</h4><p>Whereas hexose sugars are the carbohydrates transferred from plant to fungus in mycorrhyzae [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 114" title="Bonfante P, Genre A. Mechanisms underlying beneficial plant-fungus interactions in mycorrhizal symbiosis. Nat Commun. 2010;1:48." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR114" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4086">114</a>], polyols are the means by which trebouxoid algae transfer carbon to the fungus in lichens [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 115" title="Richardson DHS, Jackson Hill D, Smith DC. Lichen Physiology XI. The Role of the Alga in Determining the Pattern of Carbohydrate Movement Between Lichen Symbionts. New Phytologist. 1968;67:469–86." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR115" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4089">115</a>], and the first putative polyol transporter gene in a lichen fungus was identified recently [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 116" title="Yoshino K. SM, Sakamoto K., Yamamoto Y.: Candidates of ribitol transporter gene obtained from Ramalina conduplicans. In. cbb, 8th IAL Symposium, Poster: University of Helsinki; 2016: 116." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR116" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4092">116</a>]. We identified a family of five putative ribitol transporters in <i>C. grayi</i> (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a> and Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig10">10</a>); in coculture, only one of the five was induced (Table&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Tab3">3</a> and Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig10">10</a>), suggesting its involvement in importing ribitol to the fungus. The alga has dozens of putative sugar/MFS transporters whose expression remains mostly unchanged in coculture, except for seven that are weakly induced (Co/Mo 1.13–1.27). Their involvement, if any, in ribitol export to the fungus remains to be determined.</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-10" data-title="Fig. 10"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig10" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 10</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/10" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig10_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-10-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig10_HTML.png" alt="figure10" loading="lazy" width="685" height="367"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-10-desc"><p>A predicted ribitol transporter in <i>C. grayi</i>. <b>a</b> Differential transcription in coculture vs. monoculture of five putative sugar transporters in <i>C. grayi</i>. They were the top five BLAST hits obtained by querying the genome with the sequences of two functionally validated fungal D-sorbitol/D-mannitol/ribitol transporters [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 117" title="Pereira I, Madeira A, Prista C, Loureiro-Dias MC, Leandro MJ. Characterization of New Polyol/H+ Symporters in Debaryomyces hansenii. Plos One. 2014;9(2):e88180." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR117" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4130">117</a>]. Only CLAGR_004844-RA is induced in coculture (Co/Mo on Y axis; 1 means no induction.). <b>b</b> CLAGR_004844-RA amino acid sequence. The 12 transmembrane domains [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 118" title="Tsirigos KD, Peters C, Shu N, Kall L, Elofsson A. The TOPCONS web server for consensus prediction of membrane protein topology and signal peptides. Nucleic Acids Res. 2015;43(W1):W401–7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR118" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4137">118</a>] are indicated in bold purple. Consensus amino acids for sugar transporters [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 119" title="Leandro MJ, Fonseca C, Goncalves P. Hexose and pentose transport in ascomycetous yeasts: an overview. Fems Yeast Res. 2009;9(4):511–25." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR119" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4140">119</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 120" title="Gao ZF, Maurousset L, Lemoine R, Yoo SD, van Nocker S, Loescher W. Cloning, expression, and characterization of sorbitol transporters from developing sour cherry fruit and leaf sink tissues. Plant Physiol. 2003;131(4):1566–75." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR120" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4143">120</a>] are highlighted in cyan. <b>c</b> Protein phylogeny (PhyML, 100 bootstraps) of the five <i>C. grayi</i> transporters. The green branches correspond to nodes with bootstrap support ≥70%. The <i>C. grayi</i> proteins are labeled brown. The other transporters are identified by GI number and by fungal species. Taxa are also labeled as ascomycetes (Asco) or basidiomycetes (Basidio), the latter used as outgroup. The CLAGR_004844-RA clade is highlighted yellow. Bar indicates amino acid substitutions/site</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/10" data-track-dest="link:Figure10 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><div class="c-article-table" data-test="inline-table" data-container-section="table" id="table-3"><figure><figcaption class="c-article-table__figcaption"><b id="Tab3" data-test="table-caption">Table&nbsp;3 Selected fungal (CLAGR) and algal (Aster) genes of potential symbiotic significance differentially expressed in coculture</b></figcaption><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="table-link" data-track="click" data-track-action="view table" data-track-label="button" rel="nofollow" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/tables/3"><span>Full size table</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>It has been known since the 1970s that nitrogen is transferred from lichen mycobionts to eukaryotic photobionts [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 121" title="Rai AN, Rowell P, Stewart WDP. N-15(2) Incorporation and Metabolism in the Lichen Peltigera Aphthosa Willd. Planta. 1981;152(6):544–52." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR121" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4768">121</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 122" title="Crittenden PD. Nitrogen relations of mat-forming lichens. In: Boddy L, Merchant R, Read DJ, editors. Nitrogen, Phosphorus and Sulphur Utilization by Fungi. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press; 1989." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR122" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4771">122</a>], and more recently it was suggested that the fungus acts as a nitrogen gateway for the alga [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 123" title="Pavlova EA, Maslov AI. Nitrate uptake by isolated bionts of the lichen Parmelia sulcata. Russ J Plant Physl+. 2008;55(4):475–9." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR123" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4774">123</a>]. This hypothesis is consistent with the results of a study of the lichen <i>Cladonia portentosa</i>, which found that the response of the algal proteome to nitrogen excess was more muted than that of the fungal proteome [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 43" title="Munzi S, Sheppard LJ, Leith ID, Cruz C, Branquinho C, Bini L, Gagliardi A, Cai G, Parrotta L. The cost of surviving nitrogen excess: energy and protein demand in the lichen Cladonia portentosa as revealed by proteomic analysis. Planta. 2017." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR43" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4780">43</a>]. As is thought to be the case with mycorrhizal fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 114" title="Bonfante P, Genre A. Mechanisms underlying beneficial plant-fungus interactions in mycorrhizal symbiosis. Nat Commun. 2010;1:48." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR114" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4784">114</a>], a primary form of nitrogen released by the lichen mycobiont to the alga is likely to be ammonium, although in lichens amino acids might be involved as well [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 124" title="Elena A, Pavlova ANK, Pozdnyakov NV, Maslov AI. 15N – nitrate uptake and nitrogen exchange in the bionts of the lichen Parmelia sulcata. Symbiosis. 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR124" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4787">124</a>]. Ammonium transporters generally import NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> into the cell, but they can also export it [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Soupene E, Lee H, Kustu S. Ammonium/methylammonium transport (Amt) proteins facilitate diffusion of NH3 bidirectionally. P Natl Acad Sci USA. 2002;99(6):3926–31." href="#ref-CR125" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4793">125</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Wood CC, Poree F, Dreyer I, Koehler GJ, Udvardi MK. Mechanisms of ammonium transport, accumulation, and retention in ooyctes and yeast cells expressing Arabidopsis AtAMT1; 1. Febs Lett. 2006;580(16):3931–6." href="#ref-CR126" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4793_1">126</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Kirsten JH, Xiong YH, Davis CT, Singleton CK. Subcellular localization of ammonium transporters in Dictyostelium discoideum. Bmc Cell Biol. 2008;9:71." href="#ref-CR127" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4793_2">127</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 128" title="Palkova Z, Devaux F, Ricicova M, Minarikova L, Le Crom S, Jacq C. Ammonia pulses and metabolic oscillations guide yeast colony development. Mol Biol Cell. 2002;13(11):3901–14." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR128" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4796">128</a>]. Of particular interest are two ancient likely horizontal gene transfers of ammonium transporters from prokaryotes to fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 129" title="McDonald TR, Dietrich FS, Lutzoni F. Multiple Horizontal Gene Transfers of Ammonium Transporters/Ammonia Permeases from Prokaryotes to Eukaryotes: Toward a New Functional and Evolutionary Classification. Mol Biol Evol. 2012;29(1):51–60." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR129" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4800">129</a>]. Transporters from the earliest transfer are found in all fungi, whereas transporters from the later transfer were derived from hyperthermoacidophilic Archaea and were retained primarily by lichenizing fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 46" title="McDonald TR, Mueller O, Dietrich FS, Lutzoni F. High-throughput genome sequencing of lichenizing fungi to assess gene loss in the ammonium transporter/ammonia permease gene family. Bmc Genomics. 2013;14." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR46" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4803">46</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 129" title="McDonald TR, Dietrich FS, Lutzoni F. Multiple Horizontal Gene Transfers of Ammonium Transporters/Ammonia Permeases from Prokaryotes to Eukaryotes: Toward a New Functional and Evolutionary Classification. Mol Biol Evol. 2012;29(1):51–60." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR129" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4806">129</a>], suggesting a specific role in the symbiosis. Their selective retention might have been driven by the lichens’ frequent exposure to high temperatures and by the very low pH of their apoplast due to the high content of acidic secondary metabolites. Of the four MEthylammonium Permease-type (MEP) ammonium transporters in the <i>C. grayi</i> mycobiont, two belong to the general fungal class (CLAGR_000407-RA and CLAGR_009781-RA) and two to the class primarily retained by lichens (CLAGR_005848-RA and CLAGR_003366-RA). The <i>Cladonia</i> mycobiont also has four transporters belonging to the Gpr1/FUN34/YaaH family, whose functions are debated [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 130" title="Matthäus F, Barth G. The Gpr1/Fun34/YaaH Protein Family in the Nonconventional Yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and the Conventional Yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. In: G. B, editor. Yarrowia lipolytica, vol. 24. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer; 2013." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR130" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4815">130</a>] but include the postulated ability to export NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> in yeast [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 128" title="Palkova Z, Devaux F, Ricicova M, Minarikova L, Le Crom S, Jacq C. Ammonia pulses and metabolic oscillations guide yeast colony development. Mol Biol Cell. 2002;13(11):3901–14." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR128" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4822">128</a>], where they are named ATO (Ammonia Transport Outward). The differential transcription of these eight transporter genes is interesting: relative to fungal monoculture, in coculture with the alga five are repressed, two are induced (one strongly), and one is unchanged (Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Tab3">3</a>). The repression of a majority of these fungal transporters in coculture echoes the selective repression by the ectomycorrhizal fungus <i>A. muscaria</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 131" title="Willmann A, Weiss M, Nehls U. Ectomycorrhiza-mediated repression of the high-affinity ammonium importer gene AmAMT2 in Amanita muscaria. Curr Genet. 2007;51(2):71–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR131" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4831">131</a>] of a fungal NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> importer at the symbiotic interface, thought to prevent re-absorption by the fungus of exported NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup>. Awaiting experimental verification, we speculate that the ATO transporter CLAGR_005116-RA (Co/Mo 5.6) and perhaps the Mep1b-like ammonium transporter CLAGR_003366-RA (Co/Mo 1.5) are candidates for mediating ammonium export to the alga, while the others, probably importers, are repressed to reduce re-absorption by the fungus. In the cocultured alga relative to monoculture, expression of four of its five ammonium transporters does not change and that of the fifth is undetectably low (Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Tab3">3</a>). Overall, however, the transcriptional shifts in coculture of the fungal ammonium transporters are consistent with NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> being a major mediator of nitrogen transfer from mycobiont to photobiont. They are also consistent with the inability of freshly isolated <i>A. glomerata</i> to grow on nitrate (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec17">Specific survey of photobiont proteins involved in nitrate and CO2 assimilation</a> section).</p><p>Phosphate is an important nutrient known to be transferred from mycorrhizal fungi to their plants [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 114" title="Bonfante P, Genre A. Mechanisms underlying beneficial plant-fungus interactions in mycorrhizal symbiosis. Nat Commun. 2010;1:48." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR114" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4857">114</a>], but there is no suggestive transport polarity or coculture induction pattern among the many putative phosphate transporters in <i>A. glomerata</i> and <i>C. grayi</i> that could shed light on this system. (For other individual genes induced in coculture, see Table <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="table anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Tab3">3</a>, Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>).</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec11">Search for symbiosis-specific genes II: evolution of gene family size</h3><p>Lineage-specific expansion or contraction of multigene families is often associated with lineage-specific functional shifts in eukaryotes [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 57" title="Martin F, Aerts A, Ahren D, Brun A, Danchin EGJ, Duchaussoy F, Gibon J, Kohler A, Lindquist E, Pereda V, et al. The genome of Laccaria bicolor provides insights into mycorrhizal symbiosis. Nature. 2008;452(7183):88–U87." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR57" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4881">57</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 58" title="Martin F, Kohler A, Murat C, Balestrini R, Coutinho PM, Jaillon O, Montanini B, Morin E, Noel B, Percudani R, et al. Perigord black truffle genome uncovers evolutionary origins and mechanisms of symbiosis.
