Nature. 2010;464(7291):1033–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR58" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4884">58</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Lespinet O, Wolf YI, Koonin EV, Aravind L. The role of lineage-specific gene family expansion in the evolution of eukaryotes. Genome Res. 2002;12(7):1048–59." href="#ref-CR132" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4887">132</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Kohler A, Kuo A, Nagy LG, Morin E, Barry KW, Buscot F, Canback B, Choi C, Cichocki N, Clum A, et al. Convergent losses of decay mechanisms and rapid turnover of symbiosis genes in mycorrhizal mutualists. Nat Genet. 2015." href="#ref-CR133" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4887_1">133</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 134" title="Zuccaro A, Lahrmann U, Langen G. Broad compatibility in fungal root symbioses. Curr Opin Plant Biol. 2014;20:135–45." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR134" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4890">134</a>]. We undertook one broad and one circumscribed analysis of multigene families. For the broad survey, multigene families in <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> were identified using MCL [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 135" title="Enright AJ, Van Dongen S, Ouzounis CA. An efficient algorithm for large-scale detection of protein families. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002;30(7):1575–84." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR135" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4900">135</a>] and analyzed for changes in family size using CAFE [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 136" title="De Bie T, Cristianini N, Demuth JP, Hahn MW. CAFE: a computational tool for the study of gene family evolution. Bioinformatics. 2006;22(10):1269–71." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR136" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4903">136</a>], with the taxa listed in Methods. In <i>C. grayi</i>, 390 families were expanded, 3369 showed no change, and 769 families had undergone contraction by comparison to a putative common ancestor. In <i>Asterochloris,</i> 648 families were expanded, 2729 showed no change, and no families were contracted. The circumscribed analysis was limited to the <i>C. grayi</i> transportome and predicted 458 <i>C. grayi</i> membrane transporters using the TransportTP online tool [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 137" title="Li H, Benedito VA, Udvardi MK, Zhao PX. TransportTP: a two-phase classification approach for membrane transporter prediction and characterization. BMC Bioinformatics. 2009;10:418." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR137" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4919">137</a>] with the Transporter Classification Database [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 138" title="Saier MH, Reddy VS, Tsu BV, Ahmed MS, Li C, Moreno-Hagelsieb G. The Transporter Classification Database (TCDB): recent advances. Nucleic Acids Res. 2016;44(D1):D372–9." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR138" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4922">138</a>]. We discuss only families for which we can suggest symbiotic roles and highlight whenever a significant fraction of a gene family is also induced in coculture. We assume that the overlap of induction with expansion/contraction (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM1">1</a>) increases the likelihood that the genes involved play symbiotic roles. We did not find significantly contracted families in <i>A. glomerata</i>, although a separate search focused on nitrogen assimilation revealed a reduced set of nitrate assimilation genes in the alga (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec17">Specific survey of photobiont proteins involved in nitrate and CO2 assimilation</a> section).</p><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec12">Mycobiont expanded families</h4><p>In the <i>C. grayi</i> fungus, the most notable expansions involve 204 HET incompatibility proteins, 13 of which are also induced in coculture; 156 Ankyrin domain proteins; an 80-member family (Fam_5) of multi-transmembrane-domain proteins of unknown function with 10 coculture-induced members; Fam_668, a fructosamine kinase family with 7 members of which 3 are coculture induced; the family of polyketide synthases (PKSs) and Non-Ribosomal Peptide Synthases with at least 29 members. HET proteins might prevent incompatible <i>C. grayi</i> hyphae from fusing with a <i>C. grayi</i> mycobiont already lichenized with its photobiont. Ankyrin domains could be involved in inter-protein contacts at the symbiotic interface. Fructosamine kinases are known to reverse aging-associated protein damage produced by glycation [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 139" title="Delpierre G, Van Schaftingen E. Fructosamine 3-kinase, an enzyme involved in protein deglycation. Biochem Soc Trans. 2003;31(Pt 6):1354–7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR139" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4950">139</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 140" title="Wautier JL, Schmidt AM. Protein glycation - A firm link to endothelial cell dysfunction. Circ Res. 2004;95(3):233–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR140" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4953">140</a>]. A few of the PKSs [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 34" title="Armaleo D, Sun XM, Culberson C. Insights from the first putative biosynthetic gene cluster for a lichen depside and depsidone. Mycologia. 2011;103(4):741–54." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR34" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4957">34</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 141" title="Abdel-Hameed M, Bertrand RL, Piercey-Normore MD, Sorensen JL. Putative identification of the usnic acid biosynthetic gene cluster by de novo whole-genome sequencing of a lichen -forming fungus. Fungal Biol. 2016;120(3):306–16." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR141" id="ref-link-section-d4765e4960">141</a>] have been shown to be involved in the synthesis of the primary and most abundant secondary metabolites well known in lichens, but the large number of PKSs in <i>C. grayi</i> (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig11">11</a> and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>) points to a vast and still uncharacterized metabolic potential. Further description of these expanded families and elaboration of the hypotheses on their possible symbiotic significance are found in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>. A separate analysis identified expanded families of signal transduction components (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec15">Specific survey of mycobiont and photobiont signal transduction components</a> section&nbsp;and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM8">8</a>), some also differentially expressed in coculture (Additional files <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a> and <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM8">8</a>).</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-11" data-title="Fig. 11"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig11" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 11</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/11" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig11_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-11-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig11_HTML.png" alt="figure11" loading="lazy" width="685" height="816"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-11-desc"><p>Polyketide Synthase (PKS) and Non-Ribosomal Peptide Synthetase (NRPS) genes in <i>C. grayi</i>. The three protein categories in <b>a</b>, <b>b</b>, <b>c</b> are named on the right. CLAGR_009784 is a PKS-NRPS hybrid. The only PKS whose likely downstream product (grayanic acid) is known is CLAGR_002732 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 34" title="Armaleo D, Sun XM, Culberson C. Insights from the first putative biosynthetic gene cluster for a lichen depside and depsidone. Mycologia. 2011;103(4):741–54." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR34" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5010">34</a>]. The length of the horizontal lines is proportional to gene length (vertical gray lines delimit 3-Kb segments). Graphic symbols for protein domains are indicated at top. Genes with a suz_1 prefix were reannotated manually. See Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a> for further details</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/11" data-track-dest="link:Figure11 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec13">Mycobiont contracted families</h4><p>Carbohydrate transporter Fam_1, MFS (Major Facilitator Superfamily) Fam_2 and Fam_7, and amino acid permease Fam_22 are dramatically reduced, and some members of these families are also induced in coculture (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>) or score as slow-evolvers as discussed in <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec19">Slow-evolving proteins and anti-stress strategies in the mycobiont</a> section. The contraction of these families is part of the overall contraction observed in the specific analysis of the mycobiont’s transportome (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>). A reduced transportome has been observed also in the ectomycorrhizal ascomycete <i>T. melanosporum</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 58" title="Martin F, Kohler A, Murat C, Balestrini R, Coutinho PM, Jaillon O, Montanini B, Morin E, Noel B, Percudani R, et al. Perigord black truffle genome uncovers evolutionary origins and mechanisms of symbiosis. Nature. 2010;464(7291):1033–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR58" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5045">58</a>]. This is consistent with the loss of generalist nutrient uptake and the reliance of the fungus on a few specialized carbon sources from the photobiont, which are polyols in green algal lichens like <i>C. grayi</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 115" title="Richardson DHS, Jackson Hill D, Smith DC. Lichen Physiology XI. The Role of the Alga in Determining the Pattern of Carbohydrate Movement Between Lichen Symbionts. New Phytologist. 1968;67:469–86." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR115" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5052">115</a>] (see <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec10">Inferences from differential transcription about nutritional fluxes at the symbiotic interface</a> section).</p><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec14">Photobiont expanded families</h4><p>Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>: The most notable expansions in <i>A. glomerata</i> involve the 100-member Fam_16 of unknown proteins unique to this alga, with 20% of the members induced in coculture; Kinase families totaling 52 members; Carbohydrate Active Enzymes (CAZ) with a total of 40 members; a 29-member Ankyrin domain protein family; a probably HGT-derived family of 26 archaeal ATPase-like proteins (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a> and Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig12">12</a>). A survey using Phyre2, a protein structure prediction program [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 142" title="Jefferys BR, Kelley LA, Sternberg MJ. Protein folding requires crowd control in a simulated cell. J Mol Biol. 2010;397(5):1329–38." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR142" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5078">142</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 143" title="Kelley LA, Sternberg MJ. Protein structure prediction on the Web: a case study using the Phyre server. Nat Protoc. 2009;4(3):363–71." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR143" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5082">143</a>], suggests DNA-related functions for some Fam_16 members. The expansion of kinases matches the expanded signal transduction capability mentioned in <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec4">Genome sizes and gene organization</a> section. The expanded CAZ families might enhance the structural and biochemical versatility of the photobiont’s cell surface. The parallel expansion of Ank-domain proteins in <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> might mediate reciprocal boundary interactions. Finally, the putative ATPases of archaeal origin and the Desiccation-Related-Proteins of bacterial origin might be involved in the lichen alga’s resistance to desiccation and elevated temperatures. Further description of these expanded families and elaboration of the hypotheses on their possible symbiotic significance can be found in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>.</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-12" data-title="Fig. 12"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig12" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 12</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/12" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig12_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-12-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig12_HTML.png" alt="figure12" loading="lazy" width="685" height="585"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-12-desc"><p>Protein family tree of archaeal ATPases. The phylogram was constucted using FastTree [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 144" title="Price MN, Dehal PS, Arkin AP. FastTree 2-Approximately Maximum-Likelihood Trees for Large Alignments. Plos One. 2010;5(3):e9490." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR144" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5107">144</a>] on a MAFFT [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 145" title="Katoh K, Misawa K, Kuma K, Miyata T. MAFFT: a novel method for rapid multiple sequence alignment based on fast Fourier transform. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002;30(14):3059–66." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR145" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5110">145</a>] amino acid alignment of 91 putative archaeal ATPases from prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Branches with bootstrap values ≥0.77 are thickened. Bar indicates amino acid substitutions/site. To the ATPases present in the published <i>Galdieria</i> phylogeny [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 146" title="Schonknecht G, Chen WH, Ternes CM, Barbier GG, Shrestha RP, Stanke M, Brautigam A, Baker BJ, Banfield JF, Garavito RM, et al. Gene transfer from bacteria and archaea facilitated evolution of an extremophilic eukaryote. Science. 2013;339(6124):1207–10." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR146" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5116">146</a>], we added all the proteins above <i>Methanocaldococcus</i>_j__MJ0632 in this figure. The eukaryotic taxa shown represent most of those currently known to harbor putative archaea-derived ATPases. ATPases from <i>Galdieria</i> (Gs) are marked red, from green algae and plants green, from fungi brown. All branches in black are prokaryotic, except for the amoeba <i>Dictyostelium</i> at the base. Branch labels include the taxon name or symbol and a protein identifier. The <i>Asterochloris</i> (Aster) proteins are indicated by their gene names in the JGI database [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 68" title="Institute DJG. Asterochloris sp. Cgr/DA1pho v2.0. Available from: 
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Astpho2/Astpho2.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 8 Aug 2018." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR68" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5132">68</a>]. The phylogeny suggests several independent HGT events, but it cannot exclude a very ancient HGT from Archaea to a common eukaryotic ancestor followed by losses in most eukaryotes. <i>Asterochloris</i>, <i>Galdieria</i>, and <i>Selaginella</i> have the largest families of archaeal ATPases (with 26, 12, and 7 members, respectively). See also Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a></p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/12" data-track-dest="link:Figure12 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec15">Specific survey of mycobiont and photobiont signal transduction components</h4><p>This analysis confirms the suggestion from the data in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM3">3</a> that signal transduction protein families are expanded in <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec4">Genome sizes and gene organization</a> section). For <i>C. grayi</i>, these include PTH11-type receptors [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 147" title="Kulkarni RD, Thon MR, Pan HQ, Dean RA. Novel G-protein-coupled receptor-like proteins in the plant pathogenic fungus Magnaporthe grisea. Genome Biol. 2005;6(3)." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR147" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5180">147</a>] and components of MAPK pathways described in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM8">8</a>, together with coculture expression data collected to identify signal transduction candidates potentially involved in early fungus-alga interactions (Additional files <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a> and <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM8">8</a>). The analysis also revealed an expanded set of five divergent Gα subunit paralogs in <i>C. grayi</i> (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig13">13</a>). The <i>Asterochloris</i> expansions (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM8">8</a>) involve a more diverse set of families than <i>Cladonia</i>’s.</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-13" data-title="Fig. 13"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig13" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 13</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/13" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig13_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-13-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig13_HTML.png" alt="figure13" loading="lazy" width="685" height="555"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-13-desc"><p>A unique set of Gα subunits is present in <i>Cladonia</i>. The protein phylogeny (PhyML, 100 bootstraps) of the eight <i>C. grayi</i> Gα subunits clusters into three major MAG A, MAG B, and MAG C clades (highlighted). The unique MAG C paralogs are shown on the bottom. The green branches correspond to nodes with bootstrap support ≥67%. The <i>C. grayi</i> proteins are labeled brown. Bar indicates amino acid substitutions/site. See also Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM8">8</a></p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/13" data-track-dest="link:Figure13 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec16">Specific survey of mycobiont and photobiont transcription factor (TF) families</h4><p>Overall results are displayed in Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig14">14</a>, and specific families are listed in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM9">9</a>. With regard to overall TF family gain or loss, neither <i>Cladonia</i> nor <i>Asterochloris</i> stand out within their respective phylogenies. With regard to family expansion and contraction, <i>Asterochloris</i> also conforms to the general algal phylogeny trend of expansions outnumbering contractions. In contrast, <i>Cladonia</i> appears to have experienced more expansions of TF families than not lichenized fungi. One <i>Cladonia</i> expansion involves a group of proteins characterized by PCI domains [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 148" title="Ellisdon AM, Stewart M. Structural biology of the PCI-protein fold. Bioarchitecture. 2012;2(4):118–23." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR148" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5267">148</a>] (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM9">9</a>). PCI-domain proteins are involved in many diverse processes, and we could not find specific roles for these TFs. With regard to families with known functions, both <i>Cladonia</i> and <i>Asterochloris</i> have expanded TFs involved in chromatin remodeling (SWI/SNF [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 149" title="Tang LL, Nogales E, Ciferri C. Structure and function of SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes and mechanistic implications for transcription. Prog Biophys Mol Bio. 2010;102(2-3):122–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR149" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5280">149</a>] in <i>Cladonia</i>, SWI/SNF_Baf60 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 150" title="Jegu T, Latrasse D, Delarue M, Hirt H, Domenichini S, Ariel F, Crespi M, Bergounioux C, Raynaud C, Benhamed M. The BAF60 Subunit of the SWI/SNF Chromatin-Remodeling Complex Directly Controls the Formation of a Gene Loop at FLOWERING LOCUS C in Arabidopsis. Plant Cell. 2014;26(2):538–51." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR150" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5286">150</a>] and Sir2 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 151" title="Landry J, Sutton A, Tafrov ST, Heller RC, Stebbins J, Pillus L, Sternglanz R. The silencing protein SIR2 and its homologs are NAD-dependent protein deacetylases. P Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2000;97(11):5807–11." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR151" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5289">151</a>] in <i>Asterochloris</i>) and stress responses (SGT [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 152" title="Catlett MG, Kaplan KB. Sgt1p is a unique co-chaperone that acts as a client adaptor to link Hsp90 to Skp1p. J Biol Chem. 2006;281(44):33739–48." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR152" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5295">152</a>] and CSD [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 153" title="Mihailovich M, Militti C, Gabaldon T, Gebauer F. Eukaryotic cold shock domain proteins: highly versatile regulators of gene expression. Bioessays. 2010;32(2):109–18." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR153" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5299">153</a>] in <i>Cladonia</i>, WRKY [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 154" title="Rushton PJ, Somssich IE, Ringler P, Shen QXJ. WRKY transcription factors. Trends Plant Sci. 2010;15(5):247–58." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR154" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5305">154</a>] in <i>Asterochloris</i>). <i>Asterochloris</i> has also contracted the SET family and the CCHC zinc finger family. The contracted SET family comprises protein lysine methyltransferases, involved in methylation of histones and other proteins [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 155" title="Wu ZR, Connolly J, Biggar KK. Beyond histones - the expanding roles of protein lysine methylation. Febs J. 2017;284(17):2732–44." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR155" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5314">155</a>]. We hypothesize that selection on both symbionts’ ability to shuttle reversibly between free-living and symbiotic states [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 31" title="Armaleo D, Miao V. Symbiosis and DNA methylation in the Cladonia lichen fungus. Symbiosis. 1999;26(2):143–63." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR31" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5318">31</a>] and interact in the thallus in different ways across time and space [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 10" title="Honegger R. The symbiotic phenotype of lichen-forming ascomycetes and their endo- and epibionts. In: Hock B, editor. Fungal Associations, vol. 9. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer; 2012. p. 287–339. ISBN 978-3-642-30825-3." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR10" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5321">10</a>] produced the needed genomic plasticity through the parallel expansion of chromatin-remodeling functions. In contrast, the significant SET family contraction seems odd, given the multifaceted effects of protein lysine methylation [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 156" title="Moore KE, Gozani O. An unexpected journey: Lysine methylation across the proteome. Bba-Gene Regul Mech. 2014;1839(12):1395–403." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR156" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5324">156</a>]. We suggest that the stresses placed on lichens by repeated, rapid and large oscillations in their exposure to light, temperature and hydration might have led to the expansion of stress-related TFs in both symbionts. These environmental stresses appear to affect the evolution of many lichen adaptations [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 44" title="Carniel FC, Gerdol M, Montagner A, Banchi E, De Moro G, Manfrin C, Muggia L, Pallavicini A, Tretiach M. New features of desiccation tolerance in the lichen photobiont Trebouxia gelatinosa are revealed by a transcriptomic approach. Plant Mol Biol. 2016;91(3):319–39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR44" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5327">44</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Kranner I, Beckett R, Hochman A, Nash TH. Desiccation-tolerance in lichens: a review. Bryologist. 2008;111(4):576–93." href="#ref-CR157" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5330">157</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Steinhauser SS, Andresson OS, Palsson A, Werth S. Fungal and cyanobacterial gene expression in a lichen symbiosis: Effect of temperature and location. Fungal Biol-Uk. 2016;120(10):1194–208." href="#ref-CR158" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5330_1">158</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Wang YY, Zhang XY, Zhou QM, Zhang XL, Wei JC. Comparative transcriptome analysis of the lichen-forming fungus Endocarpon pusillum elucidates its drought adaptation mechanisms. Sci China Life Sci. 2015;58(1):89–100." href="#ref-CR159" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5330_2">159</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 160" title="Gasulla F, Jain R, Barreno E, Guera A, Balbuena TS, Thelen JJ, Oliver MJ. The response of Asterochloris erici (Ahmadjian) Skaloud et Peksa to desiccation: a proteomic approach. Plant Cell Environ. 2013;36(7):1363–78." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR160" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5333">160</a>] as discussed in <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec19">Slow-evolving proteins and anti-stress strategies in the mycobiont</a> section for the fungus (where several converge on maintaining the resilience of the proteome) and in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a> for the alga.</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-14" data-title="Fig. 14"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig14" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 14</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/14" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig14_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-14-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig14_HTML.png" alt="figure14" loading="lazy" width="685" height="699"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-14-desc"><p>Evolution of transcription factor/regulator families in fungi (left) and algae (right). All the species used and numerical data are listed in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM9">9</a>. The <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> abbreviations are bolded. Area of symbols is proportional to the change observed. Green circles: number of families gained, red circles: number of families lost. Green triangles: number of expanded families, red triangles: number of contracted families</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/14" data-track-dest="link:Figure14 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec17">Specific survey of photobiont proteins involved in nitrate and CO<sub>2</sub> assimilation</h4><p>We compared <i>A. glomerata</i> to related algae for possible adaptations involving nitrogen and carbon assimilation proteins that did not surface in the protein family screens. The top of Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig15">15</a> displays the types and organization of nitrate assimilation genes linked to a phylogenetic tree for Chlorophytes. <i>A. glomerata</i> has a reduced set of nitrate assimilation genes compared to other green algal genomes in this figure. The nitrate assimilation cluster (HANT-AC) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 161" title="Slot JC, Hibbett DS. Horizontal Transfer of a Nitrate Assimilation Gene Cluster and Ecological Transitions in Fungi: A Phylogenetic Study. Plos One. 2007;2(10):e1097." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR161" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5390">161</a>] present in most microalgae [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 162" title="Sanz-Luque E, Chamizo-Ampudia A, Llamas A, Galvan A, Fernandez E. Understanding nitrate assimilation and its regulation in microalgae. Front Plant Sci. 2015;6." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR162" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5393">162</a>] is reduced to nitrite reductase (NIR) and the NRT3 transporter in <i>A. glomerata</i>, and the total number of NNP transporters is reduced in <i>Coccomyxa subellipsoidea</i> C-169 and <i>A. glomerata</i>. <i>A. glomerata</i> has lost the clustered nitrate reductase (NAR), but it retains a nitrate reductase paralog (NAR-P) also found in <i>C. subellipsoidea</i>. Nitrate cannot be taken up directly by the lichenized alga enclosed in fungal tissue but has to be first metabolized into other compounds by the mycobiont [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 123" title="Pavlova EA, Maslov AI. Nitrate uptake by isolated bionts of the lichen Parmelia sulcata. Russ J Plant Physl+. 2008;55(4):475–9." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR123" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5412">123</a>]. These compounds may include amino acids, excreted by the fungus and presumably taken up by the alga [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 124" title="Elena A, Pavlova ANK, Pozdnyakov NV, Maslov AI. 15N – nitrate uptake and nitrogen exchange in the bionts of the lichen Parmelia sulcata. Symbiosis. 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR124" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5416">124</a>], and ammonium (see <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec10">Inferences from differential transcription about nutritional fluxes at the symbiotic interface</a> section). Congruent with these findings, <i>A. glomerata</i> isolated from <i>C. grayi</i> can grow on nitrate only after a period of adaptation to axenic culture (Armaleo, unpublished). Day 21 gene expression in mono- and coculture is graphed on the bottom of Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig15">15</a>. Interestingly, nitrate assimilation genes in <i>A. glomerata</i> are turned down about 50% in coculture relative to monoculture, which may contribute to the regulation of growth experienced by the alga when it lichenizes with the fungus [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 163" title="Hill DJ. The Control of the Cell-Cycle in Microbial Symbionts. New Phytologist. 1989;112(2):175–84." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR163" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5435">163</a>]. We hypothesize that, while <i>A. glomerata</i> is capable of autonomous nitrate assimilation utilizing nitrate transporters and NAR-P when free-living, suppression of these mechanisms during symbiosis has relaxed selection on their strict maintenance, resulting in the loss of a full HANT-AC and a reduction in the number of nitrate transporters. The extreme reduction of the nitrate assimilation toolkit in <i>A. glomerata</i> relative to other non-symbiotic chlorophytes could be viewed as a parallel to the transportome contraction in <i>C. grayi</i> (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec13">Mycobiont contracted families</a> section and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>), each contraction resulting from the almost exclusive nutritional reliance of each partner on the other.</p><div class="c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test="figure" data-container-section="figure" id="figure-15" data-title="Fig. 15"><figure><figcaption><b id="Fig15" class="c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test="figure-caption-text">Fig. 15</b></figcaption><div class="c-article-section__figure-content"><div class="c-article-section__figure-item"><a class="c-article-section__figure-link" data-test="img-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="image" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/15" rel="nofollow"><picture><source type="image/webp" srcset="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig15_HTML.png?as=webp"><img aria-describedby="figure-15-desc" src="//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1186%2Fs12864-019-5629-x/MediaObjects/12864_2019_5629_Fig15_HTML.png" alt="figure15" loading="lazy" width="685" height="694"></picture></a></div><div class="c-article-section__figure-description" data-test="bottom-caption" id="figure-15-desc"><p>Nitrate assimilation gene clustering in Chlorophytes. In the upper part of the figure, the algal phylogeny (left) and the corresponding taxa (right) bracket the gene clusters and unclustered paralogs in each taxon. Gene and cluster lengths are to scale; color codes and acronyms are listed below the 5 kb bar. Phylogeny and clusters were obtained as described in Methods. The lower part of the figure displays as vertical bars the expression levels of the nitrate assimilation genes in the alga grown alone or with the fungus. The full names of the taxa listed from top to bottom are: <i>Micromonas pusilla</i> CCMP1545; <i>Micromonas</i> RCC299; <i>Ostreococcus tauri</i>; <i>Ostreococcus lucimarinus</i>; <i>Ostreococcus sp.</i> RCC809; <i>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii</i>; <i>Volvox carteri</i>; <i>Chlorella variabilis</i> NC64A; <i>Coccomyxa subellipsoidea</i> C-169; <i>Asterochloris glomerata.</i> All the corresponding genome data are at [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 164" title="Institute DJG. Joint Genome Institute Portal. 
                    http://genome.jgi.doe.gov/
                    
                  . Accessed 15 June 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR164" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5495">164</a>]</p></div></div><div class="u-text-right u-hide-print"><a class="c-article__pill-button" data-test="article-link" data-track="click" data-track-label="button" data-track-action="view figure" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x/figures/15" data-track-dest="link:Figure15 Full size image" rel="nofollow"><span>Full size image</span><svg width="16" height="16" class="u-icon"><use xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="#global-icon-chevron-right"></use></svg></a></div></figure></div><p>As algal photosynthesis is central to the lichen symbiosis, we surveyed the carbonic anhydrases (CAs) of <i>Asterochloris</i>, enzymes that catalyze the interconversion between CO<sub>2</sub> and HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>. This adds to previous extensive work published on CAs in lichen algae [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 165" title="Palmqvist K, Sultemeyer D, Baldet P, Andrews TJ, Badger MR. Characterization of Inorganic Carbon Fluxes, Carbonic Anhydrase(S) and Ribulose-1,5-Biphosphate Carboxylase-Oxygenase in the Green Unicellular Alga Coccomyxa - Comparisons with Low-Co2 Cells of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. Planta. 1995;197(2):352–61." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR165" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5517">165</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 166" title="Palmqvist K, Badger MR. Carbonic anhydrase(s) associated with lichens: In vivo activities, possible locations and putative roles. New Phytol. 1996;132(4):627–39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR166" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5520">166</a>]. Delivery of CO<sub>2</sub> to the enclosed lichen photobionts is extremely variable, depending on the specific anatomy and physiology of its mycobiont-photobiont combination [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 167" title="Palmqvist K. Carbon economy in lichens. New Phytol. 2000;148(1):11–36." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR167" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5526">167</a>] and on rapid changes in temperature and in the supply of nutrients, water, and light [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 168" title="Lange OL. Photosynthetic productivity of the epilithic lichen Lecanora muralis: long-term field monitoring of CO2 exchange and its physiological interpretation II. Diel and seasonal patterns of net photosynthesis and respiration. Flora. 2003;198(1):55–70." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR168" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5529">168</a>]. When lichen thalli become fully saturated with water, the diffusion of CO<sub>2</sub> to the algae is further limited by the swollen hyphal tissue surrounding them. This reduces photosynthetic rates [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 169" title="Lange OL. Moisture-Content and Co2 Exchange of Lichens .1. Influence of Temperature on Moisture-Dependent Net Photosynthesis and Dark Respiration in Ramalina maciformis. Oecologia. 1980;45(1):82–7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR169" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5534">169</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 170" title="Cowan IR, Lange OL, Green TGA. Carbon-Dioxide Exchange in Lichens - Determination of Transport and Carboxylation Characteristics. Planta. 1992;187(2):282–94." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR170" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5537">170</a>] even if the hydrophobicity of the lichen interior maintains air-filled spaces for rapid CO<sub>2</sub> diffusion [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 10" title="Honegger R. The symbiotic phenotype of lichen-forming ascomycetes and their endo- and epibionts. In: Hock B, editor. Fungal Associations, vol. 9. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer; 2012. p. 287–339. ISBN 978-3-642-30825-3." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR10" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5543">10</a>]. Our data, detailed in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM10">10</a>, suggest that <i>Asterochloris</i> parallels <i>Chlamydomonas</i> and <i>Chlorella</i> in having one α CA functioning in the pyrenoid but differs in having expanded a specific subclass of cytoplasmic β CAs, whose potential relationship to the symbiosis needs exploring.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec18">Search for symbiosis-specific genes III: proteins with anomalous rates of evolution</h3><p>We hypothesize that, after a burst of adaptive selection at the origin of Lecanoromycetes 300–350 million years ago [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Schoch CL, Sung GH, Lopez-Giraldez F, Townsend JP, Miadlikowska J, Hofstetter V, Robbertse B, Matheny PB, Kauff F, Wang Z, et al. The Ascomycota Tree of Life: A Phylum-wide Phylogeny Clarifies the Origin and Evolution of Fundamental Reproductive and Ecological Traits. Syst Biol. 2009;58(2):224–39." href="#ref-CR171" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5567">171</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="de Paz GA, Cubas P, Divakar PK, Lumbsch HT, Crespo A. Origin and Diversification of Major Clades in Parmelioid Lichens (Parmeliaceae, Ascomycota) during the Paleogene Inferred by Bayesian Analysis. Plos One. 2011;6(12):e28161." href="#ref-CR172" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5567_1">172</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Gueidan C, Ruibal C, De Hoog GS, Schneider H. Rock-inhabiting fungi originated during periods of dry climate in the late Devonian and middle Triassic. Fungal Biol. 2011;115(10):987–96." href="#ref-CR173" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5567_2">173</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 174" title="Prieto M, Wedin M. Dating the Diversification of the Major Lineages of Ascomycota (Fungi). Plos One. 2013;8(6):e65576." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR174" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5570">174</a>], proteins that acquired fundamental symbiotic roles would have since stabilized under purifying selection and evolved at slower rates, as suggested for a polyketide synthase specific for a secondary metabolite unique to <i>C. grayi</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 34" title="Armaleo D, Sun XM, Culberson C. Insights from the first putative biosynthetic gene cluster for a lichen depside and depsidone. Mycologia. 2011;103(4):741–54." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR34" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5576">34</a>]. Conversely, faster evolving proteins are likely to represent more recent changes. We compared amino acid substitution rates of <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> proteins to those of eleven free-living ascomycetes and six unicellular chlorophytes respectively using three methods (Methods). We focus on the proteins whose rates were “slow” or “fast” relative to nonlichen species by at least two methods to reduce false positives. This yielded 38 slow- and 11 fast-evolving candidates in the fungus and 3 slow- and 7 fast-evolving candidates in the alga (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec19">Slow-evolving proteins and anti-stress strategies in the mycobiont</a> and <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec20">Fast-evolving proteins</a> sections).</p><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec19">Slow-evolving proteins and anti-stress strategies in the mycobiont</h4><p>Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM11">11</a> (Excel sheet “Fungus slow-evolvers”) lists a total of 72 proteins that score in multiple ways (highlighted in orange) for potential symbiotic significance. The first 38 were identified as slow-evolving by at least two of the rate methods. Of the 38, 22 are universal eukaryotic components of the protein translation, translocation and sorting machinery (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM11">11</a>). This machinery maintains proteostasis, the dynamic equilibrium of the proteome, through a complex network guiding protein folding and functionality from synthesis to modification, to sorting, and to degradation [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Lindquist SL, Kelly JW. Chemical and biological approaches for adapting proteostasis to ameliorate protein misfolding and aggregation diseases: progress and prognosis. Cold Spring Harb Perspect Biol. 2011;3(12):a004507." href="#ref-CR175" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5605">175</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Hutt DM, Balch WE. Expanding proteostasis by membrane trafficking networks. Cold Spring Harb Perspect Biol. 2013;5(7):a013383." href="#ref-CR176" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5605_1">176</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 177" title="Hartl FU, Bracher A, Hayer-Hartl M. Molecular chaperones in protein folding and proteostasis. Nature. 2011;475(7356):324–32." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR177" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5608">177</a>]. Studies with several eukaryotic systems, including yeast, show that downturns in protein translation and translocation are essential to protect cells from dehydration, heat, and hyperosmotic stresses [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Pechmann S, Willmund F, Frydman J. The ribosome as a hub for protein quality control. Mol Cell. 2013;49(3):411–21." href="#ref-CR178" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5611">178</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Pircher A, Bakowska-Zywicka K, Schneider L, Zywicki M, Polacek N. An mRNA-derived noncoding RNA targets and regulates the ribosome. Mol Cell. 2014;54(1):147–55." href="#ref-CR179" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5611_1">179</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Shalgi R, Hurt JA, Krykbaeva I, Taipale M, Lindquist S, Burge CB. Widespread regulation of translation by elongation pausing in heat shock. Mol Cell. 2013;49(3):439–52." href="#ref-CR180" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5611_2">180</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Hernandez A, Jiang X, Cubero B, Nieto PM, Bressan RA, Hasegawa PM, Pardo JM. Mutants of the Arabidopsis thaliana cation/H+ antiporter AtNHX1 conferring increased salt tolerance in yeast: the endosome/prevacuolar compartment is a target for salt toxicity. J biol Chem. 2009;284(21):14276–85." href="#ref-CR181" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5611_3">181</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Liu Y, Xiong Y, Bassham DC. Autophagy is required for tolerance of drought and salt stress in plants. Autophagy. 2009;5(7):954–63." href="#ref-CR182" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5611_4">182</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Shalgi R, Hurt JA, Lindquist S, Burge CB. Widespread Inhibition of Posttranscriptional Splicing Shapes the Cellular Transcriptome following Heat Shock. Cell Rep. 2014;7(5):1362–70." href="#ref-CR183" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5611_5">183</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 184" title="Ho YH, Gasch AP. Exploiting the yeast stress-activated signaling network to inform on stress biology and disease signaling. Curr Genet. 2015;61(4):503–11." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR184" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5615">184</a>]. In yeast for instance, many temperature-sensitive mutations impairing a variety of ribosome assembly steps also dramatically increase desiccation tolerance [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 185" title="Welch AZ, Gibney PA, Botstein D, Koshland DE. TOR and RAS pathways regulate desiccation tolerance in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Mol Biol Cell. 2013;24(2):115–28." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR185" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5618">185</a>], highlighting how slowdowns in ribosomal assembly may reduce protein misfolding and aggregation during desiccation. However, lichens must withstand daily cycles of dehydration, rehydration, thermal and UV radiation stress so extreme that they would kill most other organisms [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 157" title="Kranner I, Beckett R, Hochman A, Nash TH. Desiccation-tolerance in lichens: a review. Bryologist. 2008;111(4):576–93." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR157" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5621">157</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 186" title="Meessen J, Sanchez FJ, Brandt A, Balzer EM, de la Torre R, Sancho LG, de Vera JP, Ott S. Extremotolerance and resistance of lichens: comparative studies on five species used in astrobiological research I. Morphological and anatomical characteristics. Orig Life Evol Biosph. 2013;43(3):283–303." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR186" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5624">186</a>]. Therefore, we hypothesize that such exceptional circumstances in early lichen evolution selected for “upgraded” fungal components of the ribosomal biogenesis, mRNA processing, and protein trafficking networks, which were already part of the normal Environmental Stress Response (ESR) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 184" title="Ho YH, Gasch AP. Exploiting the yeast stress-activated signaling network to inform on stress biology and disease signaling. Curr Genet. 2015;61(4):503–11." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR184" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5627">184</a>]. The upgrades were then stabilized under purifying selection and integrated with other defenses [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 157" title="Kranner I, Beckett R, Hochman A, Nash TH. Desiccation-tolerance in lichens: a review. Bryologist. 2008;111(4):576–93." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR157" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5630">157</a>] involving, for instance, antioxidants [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 159" title="Wang YY, Zhang XY, Zhou QM, Zhang XL, Wei JC. Comparative transcriptome analysis of the lichen-forming fungus Endocarpon pusillum elucidates its drought adaptation mechanisms. Sci China Life Sci. 2015;58(1):89–100." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR159" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5634">159</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 187" title="Kranner I, Cram WJ, Zorn M, Wornik S, Yoshimura I, Stabentheiner E, Pfeifhofer HW. Antioxidants and photoprotection in a lichen as compared with its isolated symbiotic partners. P Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2005;102(8):3141–6." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR187" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5637">187</a>] and synthesis of photoprotective anthraquinones [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 188" title="Gaya E, Fernández-Brime S, Vargas R, Lachlan RF, Gueidan C, Ramírez-Mejía M, Lutzoni F. The adaptive radiation of lichen-forming Teloschistaceae is associated with sunscreening pigments and a bark-to-rock substrate shift. Proc Natl Acad Sci. 2015." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR188" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5640">188</a>] that lichens share with non-extremophiles. There is some correlative support in the literature for the centrality of ribosomal function in the lichen response to stress. In the lichen <i>Lobaria pulmonaria</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 37" title="Schneider T, Schmid E, de Castro JV Jr, Cardinale M, Eberl L, Grube M, Berg G, Riedel K. Structure and function of the symbiosis partners of the lung lichen (Lobaria pulmonaria L. Hoffm.) analyzed by metaproteomics. Proteomics. 2011;11(13):2752–6." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR37" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5646">37</a>] as much as 35% of the expressed fungal proteome is involved in ribosomal and protein turnover functions. In the lichen <i>Cladonia rangiferina</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 39" title="Junttila S, Laiho A, Gyenesei A, Rudd S. Whole transcriptome characterization of the effects of dehydration and rehydration on Cladonia rangiferina, the grey reindeer lichen. Bmc Genomics. 2013;14:870." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR39" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5653">39</a>] global transcriptional responses to desiccation and rehydration also suggest involvement of the protein translation machinery. In the cultured lichen fungus <i>Endocarpon pusillum,</i> ribosomal protein genes are highly induced during PEG-induced dehydration stress [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 159" title="Wang YY, Zhang XY, Zhou QM, Zhang XL, Wei JC. Comparative transcriptome analysis of the lichen-forming fungus Endocarpon pusillum elucidates its drought adaptation mechanisms. Sci China Life Sci. 2015;58(1):89–100." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR159" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5659">159</a>]. We speculate that the unusually high number of nuclear rDNA introns (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM12">12</a>) present in lichen fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 189" title="Bhattacharya D, Lutzoni F, Reeb V, Simon D, Nason J, Fernandez F. Widespread occurrence of spliceosomal introns in the rDNA genes of ascomycetes. Mol Biol Evol. 2000;17(12):1971–84." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR189" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5665">189</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 190" title="Gargas A, DePriest PT, Taylor JW. Positions of multiple insertions in SSU rDNA of lichen-forming fungi. Mol Biol Evol. 1995;12(2):208–18." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR190" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5668">190</a>] could be another possible adaptation to control the rate of ribosomal assembly for stress (e.g. desiccation) protection. A major consequence may be the well-known slow growth phenotype of lichens and lichen mycobionts. Other double-scoring slow evolving proteins of interest are listed and discussed in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM11">11</a>. These include a putative osmosensing calcium channel and two homogeneous groups of proteins: 18 membrane transporters and 7 aldehyde dehydrogenases (ALDHs).</p><h4 class="c-article__sub-heading c-article__sub-heading--small" id="Sec20">Fast-evolving proteins</h4><p>Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM11">11</a> includes a description of 11 putative fast-evolving mycobiont proteins involved in signal transduction, membrane trafficking and stress protection, as well as slow- and fast- evolving proteins in the photobiont.</p></div></div></section><section aria-labelledby="Sec21" data-title="Conclusions"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec21-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec21">Conclusions</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec21-content"><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec22">Symbiotically relevant genes affect stress resistance, nutritional, signaling, and structural interactions</h3><p>Our analysis identified several proteins expected to influence the symbionts’ environmental stress resistance. They include slow evolving mycobiont proteins (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec19">Slow-evolving proteins and anti-stress strategies in the mycobiont</a> section, Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM11">11</a>) enriched for universal eukaryotic components of the protein translation, translocation and sorting machinery which manages the proteome under normal as well as stress conditions like dehydration and heat [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Pechmann S, Willmund F, Frydman J. The ribosome as a hub for protein quality control. Mol Cell. 2013;49(3):411–21." href="#ref-CR178" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5706">178</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Pircher A, Bakowska-Zywicka K, Schneider L, Zywicki M, Polacek N. An mRNA-derived noncoding RNA targets and regulates the ribosome. Mol Cell. 2014;54(1):147–55." href="#ref-CR179" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5706_1">179</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Shalgi R, Hurt JA, Krykbaeva I, Taipale M, Lindquist S, Burge CB. Widespread regulation of translation by elongation pausing in heat shock. Mol Cell. 2013;49(3):439–52." href="#ref-CR180" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5706_2">180</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Hernandez A, Jiang X, Cubero B, Nieto PM, Bressan RA, Hasegawa PM, Pardo JM. Mutants of the Arabidopsis thaliana cation/H+ antiporter AtNHX1 conferring increased salt tolerance in yeast: the endosome/prevacuolar compartment is a target for salt toxicity. J biol Chem. 2009;284(21):14276–85." href="#ref-CR181" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5706_3">181</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 182" title="Liu Y, Xiong Y, Bassham DC. Autophagy is required for tolerance of drought and salt stress in plants. Autophagy. 2009;5(7):954–63." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR182" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5709">182</a>]. Also, some of the faster evolving <i>C. grayi</i> proteins, probably under adaptive selection, appear to be involved in protection from stress (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM11">11</a>). In <i>A. glomerata</i>, the likely horizontally transferred archaeal ATPases and Desiccation-Related Proteins may contribute to its heat and desiccation resistance (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec14">Photobiont expanded families</a> section, Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>). Transcription factor family expansion includes proteins involved in chromatin remodeling and stress responses in both symbionts (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec16">Specific survey of mycobiont and photobiont transcription factor (TF) families</a> section).</p><p>We also identified proteins governing several symbiotically relevant nutrient interactions. The fungus in coculture induced two transporters potentially central in the carbon and nitrogen exchange at the symbiotic interface: one an importer for ribitol, the carbon source provided by trebouxoid algae to their fungal partners [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 115" title="Richardson DHS, Jackson Hill D, Smith DC. Lichen Physiology XI. The Role of the Alga in Determining the Pattern of Carbohydrate Movement Between Lichen Symbionts. New Phytologist. 1968;67:469–86." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR115" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5734">115</a>] (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec10">Inferences from differential transcription about nutritional fluxes at the symbiotic interface</a> section and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>), the other a possible ammonium exporter (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec10">Inferences from differential transcription about nutritional fluxes at the symbiotic interface</a> section), pointing at NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> as a major nitrogen source provided by the mycobiont to the photobiont. Reliance of each partner on the other as a restricted nutrient source is also reflected by the contraction of the sugar transportome in <i>C. grayi</i> (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec13">Mycobiont contracted families</a> section) and by the reduced nitrate assimilation potential in <i>A. glomerata</i> (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec17">Specific survey of photobiont proteins involved in nitrate and CO2 assimilation</a> section). Unknown is the significance for symbiotic carbon fixation of the expansion of a specific <i>A. glomerata</i> subclass of cytoplasmic carbonic anhydrases, enzymes that catalyze the interconversion between CO<sub>2</sub> and HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec17">Specific survey of photobiont proteins involved in nitrate and CO2 assimilation</a> section and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM10">10</a>).</p><p>Gene families whose characteristics suggest involvement in other symbiotically relevant interactions comprise: signal transduction proteins, expanded in both symbionts, which include a unique new set of five MAG C paralogs in the mycobiont (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec15">Specific survey of mycobiont and photobiont signal transduction components</a> section and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM8">8</a>); ankyrin domain protein families (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec12">Mycobiont expanded families</a> and <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec14">Photobiont expanded families</a> sections), also expanded in both partners, perhaps involved in increased protein-protein interactions at the boundaries between them; algal glycosyl transferase families, whose expansion could be necessary to adapt extracellular surfaces to the varied contacts in which the photobiont engages (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec14">Photobiont expanded families</a> sections, and Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM7">7</a>); the expanded set of mycobiont polyketide synthases producing compounds for a mostly undiscovered array of biochemical functions (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec12">Mycobiont expanded families</a> section); HET incompatibility protein families in <i>C. grayi</i>, some possibly involved in the competition among fungal genotypes to secure the appropriate alga (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec12">Mycobiont expanded families</a> section). Also the induction in coculture of secreted proteins in the fungus and less prominently in the alga (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec9">Extended analysis of transcription induced in coculture</a> section) suggests their involvement in a variety of unexplored symbiotic functions.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec23">The evolution of lichenization involved changes in many conserved genes scattered throughout the symbionts’ genomes</h3><p>Most of the symbiotically relevant genes suggested here have homologs in non-lichen fungi and algae, and we assume that they are variants modified by symbiosis. This indicates that lichens evolved mainly through the accumulation of scattered regulatory and structural changes in available genes rather than through sudden key innovations. This in turn suggests that, to establish a basic and reversible nutritional dependency at very early evolutionary stages, the free-living ancestors of myco- and photobionts might have required at first only a few or even no changes. A model of such basic interactions was developed experimentally using the fungus <i>S. cerevisiae</i> and the alga <i>C. reinhardtii</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 191" title="Hom EFY, Murray AW. Niche engineering demonstrates a latent capacity for fungal-algal mutualism. Science. 2014;345(6192):94–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR191" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5825">191</a>]. Selection towards increasing stability and environmental adaptability would have then transformed such precarious mutualistic/antagonistic and reversible states into lichens over evolutionary time. This scenario suggests that there were multiple pathways for fungi, algae and cyanobacteria to evolve into lichens, which is consistent with the emerging consensus that ascolichens could have had a few independent evolutionary origins [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 171" title="Schoch CL, Sung GH, Lopez-Giraldez F, Townsend JP, Miadlikowska J, Hofstetter V, Robbertse B, Matheny PB, Kauff F, Wang Z, et al. The Ascomycota Tree of Life: A Phylum-wide Phylogeny Clarifies the Origin and Evolution of Fundamental Reproductive and Ecological Traits. Syst Biol. 2009;58(2):224–39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR171" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5828">171</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 192" title="Nelsen MP, Lucking R, Grube M, Mbatchou JS, Muggia L, Plata ER, Lumbsch HT. Unravelling the phylogenetic relationships of lichenised fungi in Dothideomyceta. Stud Mycol. 2009;64:135–44." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR192" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5831">192</a>].
