It is also compatible with the fact that lichens display a wide array of structures with different levels of complexity, from leprose and crustose to fruticose and foliose, and with the overall staggering variety of interactions throughout the biosphere between fungi and photosynthetic organisms [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 193" title="Hawksworth DL. The Variety of Fungal Algal Symbioses, Their Evolutionary Significance, and the Nature of Lichens. Bot J Linn Soc. 1988;96(1):3–20." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR193" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5835">193</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 194" title="Weiss M, Waller F, Zuccaro A, Selosse MA. Sebacinales - one thousand and one interactions with land plants. New Phytol. 2016;211(1):20–40." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR194" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5838">194</a>].</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec24">Sexual reproduction, symbiont autonomy and equivalence</h3><p>While the advantages accrued by lichens through sexual reproduction of their mycobionts are fairly clear [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 91" title="Seymour FA, Crittenden PD, Dickinson MJ, Paoletti M, Montiel D, Cho L, Dyer PS. Breeding systems in the lichen-forming fungal genus Cladonia. Fungal Genet Biol. 2005;42(6):554–63." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR91" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5849">91</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 92" title="Singh G, Dal Grande F, Cornejo C, Schmitt I, Scheidegger C. Genetic Basis of Self-Incompatibility in the Lichen-Forming Fungus Lobaria pulmonaria and Skewed Frequency Distribution of Mating-Type Idiomorphs: Implications for Conservation. Plos One. 2012;7(12)." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR92" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5852">92</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 97" title="Lee SC, Ni M, Li WJ, Shertz C, Heitman J. The Evolution of Sex: a Perspective from the Fungal Kingdom. Microbiol Mol Biol R. 2010;74(2):298–340." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR97" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5855">97</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Seymour FA, Crittenden PD, Dyer PS. Sex in the extremes: lichen-forming fungi. Mycologist. 2005;19(2):51–8." href="#ref-CR195" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5858">195</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Zoller S, Lutzoni F, Scheidegger C. Genetic variation within and among populations of the threatened lichen Lobaria pulmonaria in Switzerland and implications for its conservation. Mol Ecol. 1999;8(12):2049–59." href="#ref-CR196" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5858_1">196</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 197" title="Singh G, Dal Grande F, Werth S, Scheidegger C: Long-term consequences of disturbances on reproductive strategies of the rare epiphytic lichen Lobaria pulmonaria: clonality a gift and a curse. Fems Microbiol Ecol 2015, 91(1)." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR197" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5861">197</a>] and consistent with the behavior of a mutualistic exhabitant [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 100" title="Law R, Lewis DH. Biotic Environments and the Maintenance of Sex - Some Evidence from Mutualistic Symbioses. Biol J Linn Soc. 1983;20(3):249–76." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR100" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5865">100</a>], the advantages of sex for the algal inhabitant were previously expected to be limited [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 100" title="Law R, Lewis DH. Biotic Environments and the Maintenance of Sex - Some Evidence from Mutualistic Symbioses. Biol J Linn Soc. 1983;20(3):249–76." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR100" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5868">100</a>], mostly based on the assumption that the lichen alga is asexual and that it dies when its lichen thallus dies [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 198" title="Hill DJ. Asymmetric Co-evolution in the Lichen Symbiosis Caused by a Limited Capacity for Adaptation in the Photobiont. Bot Rev. 2009;75(3):326–38." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR198" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5871">198</a>]. As indicated in <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec6">Heterothallism probably evolved from homothallism in Cladonia; genetic evidence for sex in Asterochloris</a> section, however, there is strong evidence that sex in trebouxoid algae does occur and that free photobiont populations exist on the substrates near lichen thalli [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 27" title="Bubrick P, Galun M, Frensdorff A. Observations on free-living Trebouxia De Puymaly and Pseudotrebouxia Archibald, and evidence that both symbionts from Xanthoria parietina (L.) TH.FR. can be found free-living in nature. The New Phytolt. 1984;97:455–62." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR27" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5877">27</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 29" title="Sanders WB. Observing microscopic phases of lichen life cycles on transparent substrata placed in situ. Lichenologist. 2005;37:373–82." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR29" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5880">29</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Ott S. Sexual Reproduction and Developmental Adaptations in Xanthoria parietina. Nord J Bot. 1987;7(2):219–28." href="#ref-CR199" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5884">199</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Tschermak-Woess E. Myrmecia reticulata as a Phycobiont and Free-Living - Free-Living Treouxia – the Problem of Stenocybe septata. Lichenologist. 1978;10:69–79." href="#ref-CR200" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5884_1">200</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 201" title="Dal Grande F, Widmer I, Wagner HH, Scheidegger C. Vertical and horizontal photobiont transmission within populations of a lichen symbiosis. Mol Ecol. 2012;21(13):3159–72." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR201" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5887">201</a>], so that sexually produced variation and algal adaptations to lichenization are likely to be incorporated and selected for in lichenized populations. W.B. Sanders proposed in 2005 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 29" title="Sanders WB. Observing microscopic phases of lichen life cycles on transparent substrata placed in situ. Lichenologist. 2005;37:373–82." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR29" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5890">29</a>] that the transient free-living state is necessary for completion of the algal sexual cycle, which is consistent with the fact that the rare direct observations of algal sexual stages have always involved aposymbiotic cells (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec6">Heterothallism probably evolved from homothallism in Cladonia; genetic evidence for sex in Asterochloris</a> section). Encounters of germinating mycobiont spores and free-living photobionts [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 199" title="Ott S. Sexual Reproduction and Developmental Adaptations in Xanthoria parietina. Nord J Bot. 1987;7(2):219–28." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR199" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5896">199</a>] could produce lichens with new combinations of both genomes, expanding and fine-tuning a lichen’s adaptation to different ecological niches. Photobiont contributions to lichen adaptability are in fact highlighted by several studies. For a given lichen, the correlation of algal genotypic variation with habitat appears stronger than that of the fungal genotype [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 103" title="Kroken S, Taylor JW. Phylogenetic species, reproductive mode, and specificity of the green alga Trebouxia forming lichens with the fungal genus Letharia. Bryologist. 2000;103(4):645–60." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR103" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5899">103</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Yahr R, Vilgalys R, DePriest PT. Geographic variation in algal partners of Cladonia subtenuis (Cladoniaceae) highlights the dynamic nature of a lichen symbiosis. New Phytologist. 2006;172(2):377 (vol 171, pg 847, 2006)." href="#ref-CR202" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5903">202</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Thus H, Muggia L, Perez-Ortega S, Favero-Longo SE, Joneson S, O'Brien H, Nelsen MP, Duque-Thus R, Grube M, Friedl T, et al. Revisiting photobiont diversity in the lichen family Verrucariaceae (Ascomycota). Eur J Phycol. 2011;46(4):399–415." href="#ref-CR203" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5903_1">203</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Beiggi S, Piercey-Normore MD. Evolution of ITS ribosomal RNA secondary structures in fungal and algal symbionts of selected species of Cladonia sect. Cladonia (Cladoniaceae, Ascomycotina). J Mol Evol. 2007;64(5):528–42." href="#ref-CR204" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5903_2">204</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 205" title="Peksa O, Skaloud P. Do photobionts influence the ecology of lichens? A case study of environmental preferences in symbiotic green alga Asterochloris (Trebouxiophyceae). Mol Ecol. 2011;20(18):3936–48." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR205" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5906">205</a>]. Other analyses indicate that both fungal and algal genotypes substantially influence a lichen’s ecological adaptability [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 206" title="Widmer I, Dal Grande F, Excoffier L, Holderegger R, Keller C, Mikryukov VS, Scheidegger C. European phylogeography of the epiphytic lichen fungus Lobaria pulmonaria and its green algal symbiont. Mol Ecol. 2012;21(23):5827–44." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR206" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5909">206</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 207" title="Scheidegger C, Nadyeina O, Ardelean IV, Cheenacharoen S, Kitara NN, Wiedmer A, Werth S. Global, continental, and local genetic structure in Lobaria pulmonaria and its photobiont Dictyochloropsis reticulata. In:  The 8th IAL Symposium. Helsinki: University of Helsinki; 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR207" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5912">207</a>], and that multiple algal genotypes can coexist within single thalli [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Piercey-Normore MD. The lichen-forming ascomycete Evernia mesomorpha associates with multiple genotypes of Trebouxia jamesii. New Phytol. 2006;169(2):331–44." href="#ref-CR208" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5915">208</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Park CH, Kim KM, Elvebakk A, Kim OS, Jeong G, Hong SG. Algal and Fungal Diversity in Antarctic Lichens. J Eukaryot Microbiol. 2015;62(2):196–205." href="#ref-CR209" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5915_1">209</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 210" title="Casano LM, del Campo EM, Garcia-Breijo FJ, Reig-Arminana J, Gasulla F, del Hoyo A, Guera A, Barreno E. Two Trebouxia algae with different physiological performances are ever-present in lichen thalli of Ramalina farinacea. Coexistence versus Competition? Environ Microbiol. 2011;13(3):806–18." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR210" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5918">210</a>] and move horizontally among fungal genotypes [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 207" title="Scheidegger C, Nadyeina O, Ardelean IV, Cheenacharoen S, Kitara NN, Wiedmer A, Werth S. Global, continental, and local genetic structure in Lobaria pulmonaria and its photobiont Dictyochloropsis reticulata. In:  The 8th IAL Symposium. Helsinki: University of Helsinki; 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR207" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5922">207</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 208" title="Piercey-Normore MD. The lichen-forming ascomycete Evernia mesomorpha associates with multiple genotypes of Trebouxia jamesii. New Phytol. 2006;169(2):331–44." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR208" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5925">208</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Singh G, Dal Grande F, Divakar PK, Otte J, Crespo A, Schmitt I. Macroclimate and coevolutionary forces influence fungal-algal association patterns in Protoparmelia. In:  The 8th IAL Symposium. Helsinki: University of Helsinki; 2016." href="#ref-CR211" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5928">211</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Sadowska-Des AD, Dal Grande F, Lumbsch HT, Beck A, Otte J, Hur JS, Kim JA, Schmitt I. Integrating coalescent and phylogenetic approaches to delimit species in the lichen photobiont Trebouxia. Mol Phylogenet Evol. 2014;76:202–10." href="#ref-CR212" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5928_1">212</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Singh G, Dal Grande F, Divakar PK, Otte J, Crespo A, Schmitt I. Fungal-algal association patterns in lichen symbiosis linked to macroclimate. New Phytolt. 2017;214(1):317–29." href="#ref-CR213" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5928_2">213</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 214" title="Piercey-Normore MD, Depriest PT. Algal switching among lichen symbioses. American J Bot. 2001;88(8):1490–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR214" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5931">214</a>] even when the predominant means of photobiont transmission is vertical through vegetative propagules [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 201" title="Dal Grande F, Widmer I, Wagner HH, Scheidegger C. Vertical and horizontal photobiont transmission within populations of a lichen symbiosis. Mol Ecol. 2012;21(13):3159–72." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR201" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5934">201</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 208" title="Piercey-Normore MD. The lichen-forming ascomycete Evernia mesomorpha associates with multiple genotypes of Trebouxia jamesii. New Phytol. 2006;169(2):331–44." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR208" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5937">208</a>]. We propose therefore that, over hundreds of millions of years of tight coexistence, genomic and functional autonomy in each partner were maintained by the benefits of periodically detaching each partner from the symbiosis for sex and for partner switching, which increased the overall adaptability of the lichenized symbionts. Beyond sex, the list of phycobiont investments in the symbiosis is long. It includes the adaptations suggested in <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec14">Photobiont expanded families</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec15">Specific survey of mycobiont and photobiont signal transduction components</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec16">Specific survey of mycobiont and photobiont transcription factor (TF) families</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec17">Specific survey of photobiont proteins involved in nitrate and CO2 assimilation</a> sections, the intrinsic resilience of the free-living lichen alga to desiccation [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 44" title="Carniel FC, Gerdol M, Montagner A, Banchi E, De Moro G, Manfrin C, Muggia L, Pallavicini A, Tretiach M. New features of desiccation tolerance in the lichen photobiont Trebouxia gelatinosa are revealed by a transcriptomic approach. Plant Mol Biol. 2016;91(3):319–39." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR44" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5953">44</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 160" title="Gasulla F, Jain R, Barreno E, Guera A, Balbuena TS, Thelen JJ, Oliver MJ. The response of Asterochloris erici (Ahmadjian) Skaloud et Peksa to desiccation: a proteomic approach. Plant Cell Environ. 2013;36(7):1363–78." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR160" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5956">160</a>], the increased resistance to PSII photoinhibition in the symbiotic vs. free-living alga [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 215" title="Kosugi M, Arita M, Shizuma R, Moriyama Y, Kashino Y, Koike H, Satoh K. Responses to Desiccation Stress in Lichens are Different from Those in Their Photobionts. Plant Cell Physiol. 2009;50(4):879–88." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR215" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5960">215</a>], and correlated structural and physiological adaptations: algal morphology changes significantly between lichenized and free-living states ([<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 216" title="Peksa O, Skaloud P. Changes in chloroplast structure in lichenized algae. Symbiosis. 2008;46(3):153–60." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR216" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5963">216</a>] and references therein) and, when the lichen is hydrated, about 50% of the fixed carbon can be converted to lichen biomass [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 217" title="Palmqvist K, Dahlman, L., Jonsson, A., and Nash, T.H.: The carbon economy of lichens. In: Lichen Biology. Edited ger. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press; 2008." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR217" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5966">217</a>] with an energy conversion efficiency comparable to that with which chloroplast photosynthesis translates into plant biomass [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 218" title="Palmqvist K, Sundberg B. Light use efficiency of dry matter gain in five macro-lichens: relative impact of microclimate conditions and species-specific traits. Plant Cell Environ. 2000;23(1):1–14." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR218" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5969">218</a>]. Ribosomal DNA introns occur in lichenized trebouxoid algae [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Bhattacharya D, Friedl T, Damberger S. Nuclear-encoded rDNA group I introns: Origin and phylogenetic relationships of insertion site lineages in the green algae. Mol Biol Evol. 1996;13(7):978–89." href="#ref-CR219" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5972">219</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Friedl T, Besendahl A, Pfeiffer P, Bhattacharya D. The distribution of group I introns in lichen algae suggests that lichenization facilitates intron lateral transfer. Mol Phylogenet Evol. 2000;14(3):342–52." href="#ref-CR220" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5972_1">220</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 221" title="Nyati S, Bhattacharya D, Werth S, Honegger R. Phylogenetic Analysis of Lsu and Ssu Rdna Group I Introns of Lichen Photobionts Associated with the Genera Xanthoria and Xanthomendoza (Teloschistaceae, Lichenized Ascomycetes). J Phycol. 2013;49(6):1154–66." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR221" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5975">221</a>], including the Group IB intron in the LSU gene of <i>A. glomerata</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 221" title="Nyati S, Bhattacharya D, Werth S, Honegger R. Phylogenetic Analysis of Lsu and Ssu Rdna Group I Introns of Lichen Photobionts Associated with the Genera Xanthoria and Xanthomendoza (Teloschistaceae, Lichenized Ascomycetes). J Phycol. 2013;49(6):1154–66." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR221" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5982">221</a>]. We speculate, as for the mycobiont rDNA introns (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec19">Slow-evolving proteins and anti-stress strategies in the mycobiont</a> section), that these photobiont rDNA introns may be involved in mediating desiccation tolerance. The evolutionary introduction of <i>A. glomerata</i> or Trebouxiales to lichenization is not yet known but, based on the only published broad Chlorophyta chronogram [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 222" title="Herron MD, Hackett JD, Aylward FO, Michod RE. Triassic origin and early radiation of multicellular volvocine algae. P Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2009;106(9):3254–8." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR222" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5991">222</a>] (which does not include Trebouxiales), the timing could be compatible with that estimated for lichen fungi [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 173" title="Gueidan C, Ruibal C, De Hoog GS, Schneider H. Rock-inhabiting fungi originated during periods of dry climate in the late Devonian and middle Triassic. Fungal Biol. 2011;115(10):987–96." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR173" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5994">173</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 174" title="Prieto M, Wedin M. Dating the Diversification of the Major Lineages of Ascomycota (Fungi). Plos One. 2013;8(6):e65576." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR174" id="ref-link-section-d4765e5998">174</a>]. It is therefore possible that the <i>Asterochloris/Trebouxia</i> lineage has been adapted to symbiosis for hundreds of millions of years. Metaphorically, the lichen alga is not the “second sex” [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 223" title="de Beauvoir S. The second sex, 1st American edn. New York: Knopf; 1953." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR223" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6004">223</a>]: it deserves a full seat at the symbiotic table.</p></div></div></section><section aria-labelledby="Sec25" data-title="Methods"><div class="c-article-section" id="Sec25-section"><h2 class="c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id="Sec25">Methods</h2><div class="c-article-section__content" id="Sec25-content"><p>Where appropriate, methodological information is included in figure and table legends.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec26">Biological isolates</h3><p>The sequenced mycobiont is the <i>C. grayi</i> single-spore isolate <i>Cgr/DA2myc/ss</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 34" title="Armaleo D, Sun XM, Culberson C. Insights from the first putative biosynthetic gene cluster for a lichen depside and depsidone. Mycologia. 2011;103(4):741–54." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR34" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6029">34</a>] (Culture Bank accession # CBS 132746; GenBank ITS accession # KC592272) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 224" title="McDonald TR, Gaya E, Lutzoni F. Twenty-five cultures of lichenizing fungi available for experimental studies on symbiotic systems. Symbiosis. 2013;59(3):165–71." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR224" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6032">224</a>]. The sequenced photobiont is the <i>Asterochloris</i> strain <i>Cgr/DA1pho</i>, isolated from <i>C. grayi</i> soredia as described [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 64" title="Armaleo D, May S. Sizing the fungal and algal genomes of the lichen Cladonia grayi through quantitative PCR. Symbiosis. 2009;49(1):43–51." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR64" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6045">64</a>]. The species was identified by ITS1 sequencing and 100% identity to <i>Asterochloris glomerata</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 48" title="Skaloud P, Peksa O. Evolutionary inferences based on ITS rDNA and actin sequences reveal extensive diversity of the common lichen alga Asterochloris (Trebouxiophyceae, Chlorophyta). Mol Phylogenet Evol. 2010;54(1):36–46." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR48" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6051">48</a>]. Natural <i>C. grayi</i> podetia used for EST generation were harvested, and chemotype was confirmed by Thin Layer Chromatography as described [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 34" title="Armaleo D, Sun XM, Culberson C. Insights from the first putative biosynthetic gene cluster for a lichen depside and depsidone. Mycologia. 2011;103(4):741–54." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR34" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6058">34</a>].</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec27">Genomic DNA extraction</h3><p>The <i>C. grayi</i> mycobiont was grown for ~ 9 weeks in 50-ml cultures of HMY (MY according to Hamada [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 225" title="Hamada N. Induction of the production of lichen substances by non-metabolites. Bryologist. 1996;99(1):68–70." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR225" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6072">225</a>]: 10 g/L malt extract; 4 g/L yeast extract; 4 g/L sucrose) in 125-ml flasks shaking at room temperature, with periodic medium changes and grinding to improve growth. Typically, after 3 weeks of growth, a 50-ml mycelial culture was first ground and then expanded as follows. A Polytron homogenizer (Kinematica GmbH, model PT 10/35) fitted with an autoclaved standard 10-mm diameter probe (Brinkmann generator PTA 10S) was set up in a laminar flow hood with the probe at a 45<sup>o</sup> angle. The 50-ml culture was then sterilely ground in the tilted flask for 5 s at half-maximal setting. Using wide bore pipets, four 10-ml aliquots from the ground culture were transferred to four 125-ml flasks, each with 40 ml of fresh HMY. After every grinding, absence of contamination in each flask was tested by spreading 1 ml of the ground and diluted culture onto an HMY test plate and periodically monitoring growth by microscopy. Mycelia were harvested from the liquid cultures by filtration through nylon mesh, rinsed on the filter with sterile TE, lyophilized, weighed, and stored at -80<sup>o</sup> C. DNA was extracted from 850 mg mycelia (dry weight). The sample was thoroughly ground in a mortar with liquid nitrogen; the powder was transferred to a 50-ml polypropylene tube and resuspended in 18 ml (~ 20/1, <i>v</i>/<i>w</i>) of lysis buffer (40 mM TrisHCl pH 8; 20 mM Na Acetate; 1 mM EDTA; 1% <i>w</i>/<i>v</i> SDS) plus freshly added RNAse to 0.1 mg/ml. The suspension was repeatedly mixed with a pipet while being kept at 65<sup>o</sup> C for 5 min. A 5 M NaCl solution (6 ml) was mixed in, and the suspension was centrifuged at 3 K rpm for 5 min on a tabletop centrifuge to pellet cell debris, polysaccharides and some proteins. The supernatant was extracted with an equal volume of a 1:1 phenol:chloroform mix saturated with 100-mM Tris HCl at pH 8. The aqueous phase was brought to 65<sup>o</sup> C, and 0.11 volumes of CTAB solution (10% CTAB; 0.7 M NaCl) were mixed in. The mixture was extracted with an equal volume of chloroform. An equal volume of room-temperature isopropanol was mixed into the aqueous phase, and the solution was aliquoted into six 12-ml polypropylene tubes and centrifuged at 5<sup>o</sup> C for 15 min at 6 K rpm. After completely removing the supernatants, the procedure was repeated from the lysis buffer step in a concentrated and simplified fashion. Each pellet was first left undisturbed at 65<sup>o</sup> C for 3–5 min in 150 μl of lysis buffer plus RNAse to facilitate resuspension. The six pellets were then thoroughly resuspended by pipetting, suspensions were pooled into one of the six tubes, and 1/3 volume (300 μl) of 5 M NaCl was mixed into the pool. The solution was aliquoted into two 1.5-ml microfuge tubes, undissolved residue was removed by benchtop centrifugation for 5 min at 15 K rpm, and the supernatants were extracted once with chloroform. Two volumes of ice-cold 100% ethanol were added to the aqueous phases, and the precipitated DNA was pelleted by benchtop centrifugation at room temperature. The pellets were rinsed with 70% ethanol, air-dried in a laminar flow hood for 30 min and left undisturbed to rehydrate on ice in TE buffer overnight. They were then resuspended by gentle pipetting, and the solutions were pooled. The total yield was 127 μg of high molecular weight DNA, verified by Qubit quantitation and gel electrophoresis.</p><p><i>Asterochloris glomerata</i> was incubated on AMY plates (MY according to Ahmadjian [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 226" title="Ahmadjian V. The lichen symbiosis. New York: Wiley; 1993." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR226" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6106">226</a>]: 20 g/L malt extract; 2 g/L yeast extract) for 4 weeks at room temperature under constant light (photon flux = 40 μmol m<sup>− 2</sup> s<sup>− 1</sup>). Algae were harvested from one plate, transferred to sterile deionized water in a microfuge tube, pelleted, lyophilized, weighed and stored at -80<sup>o</sup> C. DNA was extracted from 83 mg algae (dry weight) as described [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 64" title="Armaleo D, May S. Sizing the fungal and algal genomes of the lichen Cladonia grayi through quantitative PCR. Symbiosis. 2009;49(1):43–51." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR64" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6115">64</a>], with one modification: after the final resuspension of the DNA in TE, the volume of TE was increased to 1 ml, the sample was transferred to a 12-ml Falcon tube, and the DNA was re-precipitated by adding 330 μl of 5 M NaCl followed by 2.7 ml of cold 100% EtOH. The solution was mixed by inversion and centrifuged at 6 K rpm for 10 min at 5<sup>o</sup> C. The pellet was rinsed with 70% EtOH, air-dried in a laminar flow hood for 30 min and left undisturbed to rehydrate on ice in TE buffer overnight. It was then resuspended by gentle pipetting. The total yield was 110 μg of high molecular weight DNA, verified by Qubit quantitation and gel electrophoresis.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec28">Genomic DNA sequencing, assembly, annotation and data storage</h3><p>For the mycobiont, 50,883,772 Illumina single-end reads (36 b, 52 x coverage) were pre-assembled with Velvet [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 227" title="Zerbino DR, Birney E. Velvet: Algorithms for de novo short read assembly using de Bruijn graphs. Genome Res. 2008;18(5):821–9." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR227" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6129">227</a>]. Contigs larger than 500 b were subsequently fragmented into 159,239 sub-sequences, 300 b long and with 100 b overlaps. These sub-sequences were assembled with Newbler (Roche) together with 1,486,692 single-end 454 reads (14 x coverage) and a random sub-library of 45,000 paired-end 454 reads. The resulting mycobiont 34.6 Mb draft assembly contained 414 scaffolds &gt;2Kb, with an N50 of 243,412. For the photobiont, 3,020,503 single-end 454 reads and 2,159,218 paired-end 454 reads (24.8 x total coverage) were assembled with Newbler (Roche), resulting in a 56 Mb draft assembly with 151 scaffolds and an N50 of 784,872. Completeness of draft assemblies was assessed by screening for the presence of 248 core eukaryotic genes with CEGMA (Core Eukaryotic Genes Mapping Approach) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 228" title="Parra G, Bradnam K, Ning ZM, Keane T, Korf I. Assessing the gene space in draft genomes. Nucleic Acids Res. 2009;37(1):289–97." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR228" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6132">228</a>], a now discontinued pipeline to annotate highly conserved Core Eukaryotic Genes (CEGs). In the mycobiont assembly, 234 (94.35%) CEGs were fully recovered, and scores increased to 241 (97.18%) if partial hits were considered as well. In the photobiont assembly, 216 complete (87.10%) and 235 partial (94.6%) CEGs were recovered. Gene model annotation was performed with MAKER2 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 229" title="Holt C, Yandell M. MAKER2: an annotation pipeline and genome-database management tool for second-generation genome projects. BMC Bioinformatics. 2011;12:418." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR229" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6135">229</a>]. For the mycobiont, assembled <i>C. grayi</i> mRNA-seq reads (see next section) were used as EST evidence, and the gene prediction tool SNAP [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 230" title="Korf I. Gene finding in novel genomes. BMC Bioinformatics. 2004;5:59." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR230" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6141">230</a>] was trained through MAKER2 with <i>C. grayi</i> protein annotations from the earlier JGI genome release [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 231" title="Institute DJG. Cladonia grayi Cgr/DA2myc/ss v1.0. [
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Clagr2/Clagr2.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 15 June 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR231" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6148">231</a>] and the 248 eukaryotic core protein sequences of CEGMA. Annotations were additionally complemented by Genemark-ES [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 232" title="Ter-Hovhannisyan V, Lomsadze A, Chernoff YO, Borodovsky M. Gene prediction in novel fungal genomes using an ab initio algorithm with unsupervised training. Genome Res. 2008;18(12):1979–90." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR232" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6151">232</a>] trained on the assembled <i>C. grayi</i> genome, and generated models were passed to MAKER2. For the&nbsp;photobiont, assembled <i>A. glomerata</i> mRNA-seq reads (see next section) and <i>Coccomyxa sp.</i> C-169 ESTs [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 233" title="Institute DJG. Coccomyxa sp. C-169. 
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Coc_C169_1/Coc_C169_1.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 15 June 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR233" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6164">233</a>] were used as EST evidence, and SNAP was trained through MAKER2 with <i>A. glomerata</i> protein annotations from the earlier JGI genome release [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 234" title="Institute DJG. Asterochloris sp. Cgr/DA1pho v1.0. 
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Astpho1/Astpho1.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 15 June 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR234" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6170">234</a>]. Annotations were additionally complemented by Genemark-ES trained on the assembled <i>A. glomerata</i> genome, and generated models were passed to MAKER2. In the mycobiont, 11,398 gene models were predicted, including 115 isoforms, and 10,075 gene models were predicted in the photobiont. The annotated and searchable genome assemblies are at [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 67" title="Institute DJG. Cladonia grayi Cgr/DA2myc/ss v2.0. Available from: 
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Clagr3/Clagr3.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 8 Aug 2018." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR67" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6176">67</a>] for the mycobiont and at [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 68" title="Institute DJG. Asterochloris sp. Cgr/DA1pho v2.0. Available from: 
                    https://genome.jgi.doe.gov/Astpho2/Astpho2.home.html
                    
                  . Accessed 8 Aug 2018." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR68" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6179">68</a>] for the photobiont.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec29">RNA extraction and EST generation from whole lichen thalli</h3><p>Total RNA for EST generation was extracted from freshly harvested <i>C. grayi</i> podetia treated with RNAlater (ThermoFisher) to prevent RNA degradation. Dirt was removed with tweezers, and podetia were left to dry at room temperature and moisture for 2 h and weighed (200 mg). RNAlater permeates dry better than moist tissue, and RNA quality is not significantly affected by this brief period of “natural” drying, as lichens are exposed to drying in nature. RNAlater was added (2 ml/100 mg podetia) and the suspension was vortexed until all air pockets were removed, indicating an even permeation of the solvent into the tissues. Podetia were kept in RNAlater at room temperature for about 1 h with occasional mixing. Excess RNAlater was removed by centrifugation, followed by gentle blotting of the podetia with filter paper. Podetia were lyophilized overnight and stored at -80<sup>o</sup> C. Podetia were thoroughly ground in liquid nitrogen with a mortar, and RNA was extracted with the RNAqueous Total RNA Isolation Kit (Life Technologies) according to the manufacturer’s protocol with two modifications. For the first, the initial buffer volume in which the ground powder was resuspended was increased to 5 ml Lysis Buffer mixed with 680 μl of Plant Isolation Aid for 200 mg of air-dried podetia. For the second, a DNAse-treatment step was inserted as follows. After loading the lysate onto the cartridge and centrifuging to remove residual Lysis Buffer-Plant Isolation Aid solution, 500 μl of Wash 2/3 solution were centrifuged through the cartridge. The cartridge was then centrifuged again without added liquid to remove all traces of Wash 2/3. After moving the cartridge to a new collection tube, the matrix was wetted by adding 60 μl of DNAse solution (52 μl RNase-free water, 6 μl 10xDNase buffer Promega M198A, 2 μl RQ1 RNase-free DNase Promega M610A). Under these conditions, nucleic acids detach from but remain within the matrix. After incubating the cartridge with DNase at 37<sup>o</sup> C for 15 min, 300 μl of a 1:1 mix of Lysis Buffer: 64% ethanol were added to allow the RNA to bind again to the matrix. The cartridge was kept at room temperature for 5 min, and the liquid was removed by centrifugation. The manufacturer’s protocol was resumed by adding 700 μl of Wash 1. The final yield was 27 μg of purified RNA. Agilent microchip electrophoresis showed a RIN = 9. The RNA was used to prepare a 454 cDNA library of 740,680 reads averaging around 500 bases in length. Of the reads, 76.2% mapped onto the mycobiont genome and 12.1% onto the photobiont genome. The residual unmapped reads are from other eukaryotic or prokaryotic inhabitants of natural <i>C. grayi</i> thalli. Reads were assembled into ESTs using Newbler (Roche), Velvet [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 227" title="Zerbino DR, Birney E. Velvet: Algorithms for de novo short read assembly using de Bruijn graphs. Genome Res. 2008;18(5):821–9." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR227" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6201">227</a>] and Trinity [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 235" title="Grabherr MG, Haas BJ, Yassour M, Levin JZ, Thompson DA, Amit I, Adiconis X, Fan L, Raychowdhury R, Zeng QD, et al. Full-length transcriptome assembly from RNA-Seq data without a reference genome. Nat Biotechnol. 2011;29(7):644–U130." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR235" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6205">235</a>], and mapped to the assembled symbiont genomes to aid in the annotation (see preceding section).</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec30">RNA extraction and sequencing for analysis of differential expression in coculture</h3><p>To analyze differential gene expression during symbiont coculture in vitro, RNA was isolated from mycobiont and photobiont grown on filters in agar plates. The culturing details are as described [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 33" title="Joneson S, Armaleo D, Lutzoni F. Fungal and algal gene expression in early developmental stages of lichen-symbiosis. Mycologia. 2011;103(2):291–306." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR33" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6216">33</a>]. Briefly, mycobiont and photobiont were routinely propagated as described for the DNA extractions. To set up filter cultures, separate fungal and algal cultures were harvested and filtered first through gauze and then through 74 μm nylon to obtain uniform suspensions either of small mycelial fragments or of algal cells. Cell density of the separated suspensions was measured by OD, and fixed amounts (dry weight equivalents: 2.9 mg mycobiont and/or 1.3 mg photobiont) were uniformly delivered by suction onto 0.22 μm pore-size nitrocellulose filters (Millipore, GSWP04700) to obtain cultures of either fungus alone, alga alone, or the two together. The seeded filters were placed on 1.5% agarose (Sigma-Aldrich A9539) plates (one filter per plate) with “99:1” medium [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 33" title="Joneson S, Armaleo D, Lutzoni F. Fungal and algal gene expression in early developmental stages of lichen-symbiosis. Mycologia. 2011;103(2):291–306." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR33" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6219">33</a>] and incubated for 21 days at room temperature under a constant photon flux of 40 μmol m<sup>− 2</sup> s<sup>− 1</sup> (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig6">6</a>). The main methodological difference relative to Joneson et al. (2011) [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 33" title="Joneson S, Armaleo D, Lutzoni F. Fungal and algal gene expression in early developmental stages of lichen-symbiosis. Mycologia. 2011;103(2):291–306." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR33" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6230">33</a>] was the addition of RNAlater at harvest. Each filter was peeled off the agarose surface and placed over three stacked Whatman 9-cm filter paper disks in the lid of a 10-cm plastic Petri dish. To exchange residual growth medium for RNAlater, 2 × 1 ml of RNAlater were evenly pipetted over the entire surface of the nitrocellulose filter culture. After the RNAlater was absorbed by the Whatman filters, the nitrocellulose filter was placed (culture facing up) into the empty bottom half of the Petri dish, and 1 ml RNAlater was uniformly pipetted over it. While submerged in the RNAlater layer, the culture was scraped off the nitrocellulose with a sterile blade, pooled to the edge in RNAlater by tilting the dish, and the suspension was pipetted into a microfuge tube. Addition of 1 ml RNAlater, scraping and pooling were repeated once more, and the two suspensions were kept in two tubes for 1 h at room temperature. To obtain a single pellet from the two tubes corresponding to one filter, the two suspensions were centrifuged sequentially in the same tube, the RNAlater was discarded, and the pellet was lyophilized and stored at -80<sup>o</sup> C. Each frozen pellet was ground with a fitting pestle in its microcentrifuge tube cooled in liquid nitrogen [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 31" title="Armaleo D, Miao V. Symbiosis and DNA methylation in the Cladonia lichen fungus. Symbiosis. 1999;26(2):143–63." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR31" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6235">31</a>]. The ground powder derived from one filter culture was resuspended in 500 μl of Lysis Buffer-Plant Isolation Aid combination (RNAqueous Total RNA Isolation Kit, Life Technologies), and RNA was extracted according to the manufacturer’s instructions except for the insertion of a DNAse treatment step as described in the preceding section. For each growth condition, the extracts from two replicate cultures were combined. RNA yields per combined cultures were 3 μg, 7 μg and 16 μg respectively from fungus alone, alga alone, and coculture. Agilent microchip electrophoresis showed RINs near 9. The RNA was used to produce cDNA libraries totaling 156 million RNAseq reads. Reads were aligned using Bowtie [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 236" title="Langmead B, Trapnell C, Pop M, Salzberg SL. Ultrafast and memory-efficient alignment of short DNA sequences to the human genome. Genome Biol. 2009;10(3)." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR236" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6238">236</a>]. Gene expression was calculated using BowStrap [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 237" title="Larsen PE, Collart FR. BowStrap v1.0: Assigning statistical significance to expressed genes using short-read transcriptome data. BMC Res Notes. 2012;5:275." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR237" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6241">237</a>] with the annotated gene models from the mycobiont and photobiont genomes at JGI. Gene expression is defined as re-sampled Reads Per Kilobase of gene sequence per Million aligned sequences (RPKM). For the GO term-centered analysis, differential expression was represented as the ratio between the base 2 logs of each gene’s coculture and monoculture RPKMs on day 21. Genes with log fold changes &gt; 0.6 (for upregulation) and &lt; 0.6 (for downregulation) were analyzed. Statistical significance (<i>p</i> &lt; 0.05) was based on hypergeometric distribution enrichment of genes or pathways relative to their representation in the whole genome. For the more extensive analysis (<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="section anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Sec9">Extended analysis of transcription induced in coculture</a> section), the ratio between each gene’s coculture and monoculture RPKMs on day 21 (referred to here as Co/Mo) was taken directly to represent differential expression, and only ratios &gt; 2 for the mycobiont or &gt; 1.3 for the photobiont were considered induced. To combine the induced genes/proteins (795 in the mycobiont and 471 in the photobiont) into functionally related protein subgroups, we collected information from GO terms, PFAM domains, and literature searches (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM6">6</a>). Statistical significance (p &lt; 0.05) for the coculture induction of each resulting subgroup (Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig8">8</a>) was based on that subgroup’s hypergeometric distribution enrichment within all induced proteins relative to the representation, in the whole genome, of genes encoding proteins similar to those in that subgroup. Such proteins were identified (e-value &lt;1e<sup>− 5</sup>) by using the subgroup as query in a BLASTP genome search.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec31">Predictions of multigene families, PKSs, and secreted proteins</h3><p>Protein sequences for multigene family analysis were retrieved from the Joint Genome Institute Portal [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 164" title="Institute DJG. Joint Genome Institute Portal. 
                    http://genome.jgi.doe.gov/
                    
                  . Accessed 15 June 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR164" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6267">164</a>] and the Broad Institute Portal [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 238" title="Institute B. Data, Software and Tools. 
                    https://www.broadinstitute.org/data-software-and-tools
                    
                  . Accessed 5 Feb 2016." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR238" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6270">238</a>]. As references for <i>Cladonia grayi</i>, the following fungal taxa were used: <i>Stagonospora nodorum</i> (<i>Phaeosphaeria nodorum</i>) (16,597 models), <i>Botrytis cinerea</i> (<i>Botryotinia fuckeliana</i>) (16,389 models), <i>Sclerotinia sclerotiorum</i> (14,522 models), <i>Neurospora crassa</i> (9907 models), <i>Aspergillus nidulans</i> (10,753 models), <i>Aspergillus fumigatus</i> (9887 models), <i>Aspergillus oryzae</i> (12,017 models), <i>Tuber melanosporum</i> (7496 models), <i>Fusarium graminearum</i> (13,826 models), <i>Pyrenophora tritici-repentis</i> (12,169 models) and <i>Chaetomium globosum</i> (11,103 models). As references for <i>Asterochloris glomerata</i>, the following algal taxa were used: <i>Coccomyxa</i> sp. C169 (9629 models), <i>Chlorella</i> sp. NC64A (9791 models), <i>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii</i> 169 (17,113 models), <i>Ostreococcus tauri</i> (7725 models), <i>Volvox carteri</i> (14,542 models), and <i>Micromonas sp</i>. CCMP1545 (10,545 models). Orthogroups of mutual best BLAST hits present in the symbiont genomes and all reference species (2455 in <i>C. grayi</i>, 1454 in <i>A. glomerata</i>) were further analyzed. Protein groups were aligned with MAFFT [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 145" title="Katoh K, Misawa K, Kuma K, Miyata T. MAFFT: a novel method for rapid multiple sequence alignment based on fast Fourier transform. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002;30(14):3059–66." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR145" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6346">145</a>] using <i>Tuber melanosporum</i> or <i>Volvox carteri</i> as outgroups, and alignments were subsequently trimmed with GBLOCKS [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 239" title="Castresana J. Selection of conserved blocks from multiple alignments for their use in phylogenetic analysis. Mol Biol Evol. 2000;17(4):540–52." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR239" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6355">239</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 240" title="Talavera G, Castresana J. Improvement of phylogenies after removing divergent and ambiguously aligned blocks from protein sequence alignments. Syst Biol. 2007;56(4):564–77." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR240" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6359">240</a>] (<i>A. glomerata</i>) and Guidance [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 241" title="Penn O, Privman E, Landan G, Graur D, Pupko T. An Alignment Confidence Score Capturing Robustness to Guide Tree Uncertainty. Mol Biol Evol. 2010;27(8):1759–67." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR241" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6365">241</a>] (<i>C. grayi</i>). Proteins were queried in an all-against-all BLASTP analysis, and protein families were subsequently predicted with MCL [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 135" title="Enright AJ, Van Dongen S, Ouzounis CA. An efficient algorithm for large-scale detection of protein families. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002;30(7):1575–84." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR135" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6371">135</a>] with inflation parameters set to 3.0. In the fungal data set, 5051 protein families were identified that were phylogenetically relevant (containing at least two species and 10 sequences), of which 4528 were found in <i>C. grayi</i>. In the algal data set, 3545 phylogenetically relevant gene families were identified. <i>C. grayi</i> PKSs and NRPSs were predicted using antiSMASH v3.0 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 242" title="Weber T, Blin K, Duddela S, Krug D, Kim HU, Bruccoleri R, Lee SY, Fischbach MA, Muller R, Wohlleben W, et al. antiSMASH 3.0-a comprehensive resource for the genome mining of biosynthetic gene clusters. Nucleic Acids Res. 2015;43(W1):W237–43." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR242" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6381">242</a>], followed by manual curation. Secreted proteins in <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> were predicted as indicated in the legend of Fig. <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig9">9</a>.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec32">Analysis of gene family expansions and contractions</h3><p>For the broad analysis encompassing all <i>C. grayi</i> and <i>A. glomerata</i> genes, multigene families predicted as described in the previous section were analyzed for evolutionary changes in protein family size using CAFE [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 136" title="De Bie T, Cristianini N, Demuth JP, Hahn MW. CAFE: a computational tool for the study of gene family evolution. Bioinformatics. 2006;22(10):1269–71." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR136" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6407">136</a>]. The program uses a random birth and death model of gene gain and loss across a user-specified tree structure. The distribution of family sizes generated under the random model provides a basis for assessing the significance of the observed family size differences among taxa (<i>p</i>-value &lt; 0.001). CAFE estimates for each branch in the tree whether a protein family has not changed, has expanded or has contracted. For the analysis of <i>C. grayi</i> family expansion and contraction centered on the transportome, predicted proteins containing at least three transmembrane domains were extracted from the same fungal genomes used in the broad analysis and listed in the previous section. These predicted proteins were classified according to the Transport Classification database [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 138" title="Saier MH, Reddy VS, Tsu BV, Ahmed MS, Li C, Moreno-Hagelsieb G. The Transporter Classification Database (TCDB): recent advances. Nucleic Acids Res. 2016;44(D1):D372–9." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR138" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6417">138</a>] using the TransportTP on-line tool [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 137" title="Li H, Benedito VA, Udvardi MK, Zhao PX. TransportTP: a two-phase classification approach for membrane transporter prediction and characterization. BMC Bioinformatics. 2009;10:418." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR137" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6420">137</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 243" title="TransportTP: A Transporter Prediction Server. 
                    http://bioinfo3.noble.org/transporter/
                    
                  ." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR243" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6423">243</a>]. For several families, classifications were checked manually with predicted fungal transporter proteins retrieved from TCDB, TransportDB [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 244" title="Elbourne LDH, Tetu SG, Hassan KA, Paulsen IT. TransportDB 2.0: a database for exploring membrane transporters in sequenced genomes from all domains of life. Nucleic Acids Res. 2017;45(D1):D320–4." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR244" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6426">244</a>], and the <i>Saccharomyces</i> Genome Database [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 245" title="Stanford University DoG. Saccharomyces Genome Database. 
                    http://www.yeastgenome.org/
                    
                  . Accessed 2 July 2017." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR245" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6432">245</a>] used as queries in BLASTP and TBLASTX searches against the 12 fungal genomes. Lineage-specific gene gains and losses were estimated using CAFE [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 136" title="De Bie T, Cristianini N, Demuth JP, Hahn MW. CAFE: a computational tool for the study of gene family evolution. Bioinformatics. 2006;22(10):1269–71." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR136" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6436">136</a>].</p><p>For the analysis centered on signal transduction components, predicted proteins were identified based on PFAM domains among the taxa indicated above. To identify family expansions and contractions, protocols similar to those indicated above were used. For the analysis centered on putative DNA-binding transcription factors (TFs), the proteomes of the fungal and algal taxa indicated in Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM9">9</a> were searched using the hmmscan module of HMMER version 3.0 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 246" title="S.R.E. HMMER: biosequence analysis using profile hidden Markov models. 
                    http://hmmer.org/
                    
                  . Accessed 22 July 2017." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR246" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6445">246</a>] against a comprehensive DNA-binding domain database assembled from three compilations [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Shelest E. Transcription factors in fungi. Fems Microbiol Lett. 2008;286(2):145–51." href="#ref-CR247" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6448">247</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" title="Park J, Park J, Jang S, Kim S, Kong S, Choi J, Ahn K, Kim J, Lee S, Kim S, et al. FTFD: an informatics pipeline supporting phylogenomic analysis of fungal transcription factors. Bioinformatics. 2008;24(7):1024–5." href="#ref-CR248" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6448_1">248</a>,<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 249" title="Lang D, Weiche B, Timmerhaus G, Richardt S, Riano-Pachon DM, Correa LGG, Reski R, Mueller-Roeber B, Rensing SA. Genome-Wide Phylogenetic Comparative Analysis of Plant Transcriptional Regulation: A Timeline of Loss, Gain, Expansion, and Correlation with Complexity. Genome Biol Evol. 2010;2:488–503." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR249" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6451">249</a>] to which corresponding PFAM domain designations were assigned. GA (gathering bitscore) thresholds for each domain were retrieved from PFAM 25.0, and each hit on a protein exceeding the appropriate GA threshold was recorded. Matches where alignments covered less than 80% of the corresponding PFAM profile HMM were discarded. Putative transcription factors were classified into families based on domain structure as described by Lang et al. [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 249" title="Lang D, Weiche B, Timmerhaus G, Richardt S, Riano-Pachon DM, Correa LGG, Reski R, Mueller-Roeber B, Rensing SA. Genome-Wide Phylogenetic Comparative Analysis of Plant Transcriptional Regulation: A Timeline of Loss, Gain, Expansion, and Correlation with Complexity. Genome Biol Evol. 2010;2:488–503." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR249" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6454">249</a>] and rules were extended by incorporating fungal-specific terms. A random birth and death model [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 250" title="Csuros M, Miklos I. Streamlining and Large Ancestral Genomes in Archaea Inferred with a Phylogenetic Birth-and-Death Model. Mol Biol Evol. 2009;26(9):2087–95." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR250" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6458">250</a>] was used to investigate expansions, contractions, gains, losses and ancestral states of TF families across algal and fungal phylogenies [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 4" title="Arnold AE, Miadlikowska J, Higgins KL, Sarvate SD, Gugger P, Way A, Hofstetter V, Kauff F, Lutzoni F. A Phylogenetic Estimation of Trophic Transition Networks for Ascomycetous Fungi: Are Lichens Cradles of Symbiotrophic Fungal Diversification? Syst Biol. 2009;58(3):283–97." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR4" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6461">4</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 251" title="Marcet-Houben M, Gabaldon T. The Tree versus the Forest: The Fungal Tree of Life and the Topological Diversity within the Yeast Phylome. Plos One. 2009;4(2):e4357." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR251" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6464">251</a>] (Fig.&nbsp;<a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="figure anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#Fig14">14</a>). The best model was selected from a series of models with increasing complexity by using likelihood ratio tests to drop parameters that did not further improve the likelihood of a model. After rate parameter optimization, posterior probability of ancestral gene content of each node and the evolutionary change for each family along the branches of the tree were estimated.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec33">Analysis of nitrate assimilation genes in chlorophytes</h3><p>Homologs of nitrate assimilation-related (HANT) genes (<i>C. reinhardtii</i>: nitrate reductase, AAF17595.1; nitrite reductase, XP_001696787.1; NRT2, XP_001696788.1; formate/nitrite transporter, XP_001696698.1; <i>M. pusilla</i>: nitrite reductase, XP_003057941.1; molybdopterin synthase, XP_003057940.1) were determined by BLASTP of algal genome best protein models (<i>Asterochloris glomerata</i> Cgr/DA1pho v1.0, <i>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii</i> v4.0, <i>Chlorella sp.</i> NC64A v1.0, <i>Coccomyxa</i> sp. C-169 v2.0, <i>Micromonas pusilla</i> CCMP1545 v 2.0, <i>Micromonas commoda</i> NOUM17 (RCC 299) v 2.0, <i>Volvox carteri nagariensis</i> v 1.0, <i>Ostreococcus</i> sp. RCC809 v 2.0, <i>Ostreococcus lucimarinus</i> v 2.0, <i>Ostreococcus tauri</i> RCC4221 v3.0). Retained hits had at least 45% similarity with and covered between 50 and 150% of the length of the query. Homologs of the query genes were considered part of a nitrate assimilation cluster (HANT-AC) if separated by no more than 6 intervening gene models from another gene in the query [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 252" title="Wisecaver JH, Slot JC, Rokas A. The Evolution of Fungal Metabolic Pathways. Plos Genet. 2014;10(12):e1004816." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR252" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6516">252</a>]. Intervening and flanking sequence up to 10 kb of HANT-ACs were examined for unannotated nitrate assimilation-related genes by BLASTX against the NCBI non-redundant protein database; NRT3 was determined by the presence of NAR2 PFAM domain. Orthology and paralogy of nitrate assimilation genes were determined by examination of phylogenetic trees generated as follows: protein sequences were aligned with MAFFT v.7.2.2.1 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 145" title="Katoh K, Misawa K, Kuma K, Miyata T. MAFFT: a novel method for rapid multiple sequence alignment based on fast Fourier transform. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002;30(14):3059–66." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR145" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6519">145</a>] using default parameters, and poorly aligned regions were removed with trimAl v.1.4 using the “automated1” algorithm [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 253" title="Capella-Gutierrez S, Silla-Martinez JM, Gabaldon T. trimAl: a tool for automated alignment trimming in large-scale phylogenetic analyses. Bioinformatics. 2009;25(15):1972–3." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR253" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6522">253</a>]. The best model of protein evolution (JTT, WAG, LG) was inferred by AICc using ProtTest v.3.4 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 254" title="Abascal F, Zardoya R, Posada D. ProtTest: selection of best-fit models of protein evolution. Bioinformatics. 2005;21(9):2104–5." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR254" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6525">254</a>], and maximum likelihood analysis was performed with RAxML v.8.1.20 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 255" title="Stamatakis A. RAxML-VI-HPC: Maximum likelihood-based phylogenetic analyses with thousands of taxa and mixed models. Bioinformatics. 2006;22(21):2688–90." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR255" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6528">255</a>]. Nitrite reductase phylogeny was estimated using the combined sequences from both BLAST searches and was reduced to models containing a PLN02431 protein domain. Expected but missing gene homologs were considered absent by TBLASTN of the respective genome assemblies. Algal species phylogeny was estimated by analysis of <i>RPB2</i> using the methods above.</p><h3 class="c-article__sub-heading" id="Sec34">
                           <i>A. glomerata</i> meiosis gene identification and phylogenetic analysis; flagellar proteins</h3><p>We sought <i>A. glomerata</i> orthologs of multiple meiosis-specific genes proposed as a “meiosis detection toolkit” for identifying genomic evidence for sexual reproduction ([<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 256" title="Schurko AM, Logsdon JM. Using a meiosis detection toolkit to investigate ancient asexual &quot;scandals&quot; and the evolution of sex. Bioessays. 2008;30(6):579–89." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR256" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6550">256</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 257" title="Malik SB, Pightling AW, Stefaniak LM, Schurko AM, Logsdon JM. An Expanded Inventory of Conserved Meiotic Genes Provides Evidence for Sex in Trichomonas vaginalis. Plos One. 2008;3(8):e2879." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR257" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6553">257</a>] and references therein) and select paralogs: <i>Msh4</i>; <i>Msh5</i>; <i>Asy1</i>/<i>Hop1</i>; <i>Ahp2</i>/<i>Hop2</i>; <i>Mnd1</i>; <i>Dmc1</i> (paralog <i>Rad51</i>—DNA repair in meiosis and mitosis); <i>Syn1</i>/<i>Rec8</i> (paralogs <i>Syn2</i>, <i>Syn3</i>, <i>Syn4</i>—cohesins not specific to meiosis [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 258" title="Schubert V, Weissleder A, Ali H, Fuchs J, Lermontova I, Meister A, Schubert I. Cohesin gene defects may impair sister chromatid alignment and genome stability in Arabidopsis thaliana. Chromosoma. 2009;118(5):591–605." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR258" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6601">258</a>]); <i>Spo11–1</i>, <i>Spo11–2</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 259" title="Stacey NJ, Kuromori T, Azumi Y, Roberts G, Breuer C, Wada T, Maxwell A, Roberts K, Sugimoto-Shirasu K. Arabidopsis SPO11-2 functions with SPO11-1 in meiotic recombination. Plant J. 2006;48(2):206–16." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR259" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6610">259</a>] (paralog <i>Spo11–3</i>—no reported meiotic phenotype; affects overall plant size, hormone responses, and endoreduplication [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 260" title="Sugimoto-Shirasu K, Stacey NJ, Corsar J, Roberts K, McCann MC. DNA topoisomerase VI is essential for endoreduplication in Arabidopsis. Curr Biol. 2002;12(20):1782–6." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR260" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6616">260</a>]). We also sought orthologs of two additional meiosis-specific genes: <i>Pch2</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 261" title="Lambing C, Osman K, Nuntasoontorn K, West A, Higgins JD, Copenhaver GP, Yang J, Armstrong SJ, Mechtler K, Roitinger E, et al. Arabidopsis PCH2 Mediates Meiotic Chromosome Remodeling and Maturation of Crossovers. Plos Genet. 2015;11(7):e1005372." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR261" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6623">261</a>] and <i>Mer3</i> [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 262" title="Chen CB, Zhang W, Timofejeva L, Gerardin Y, Ma H. The Arabidopsis ROCK-N-ROLLERS gene encodes a homolog of the yeast ATP-dependent DNA helicase MER3 and is required for normal meiotic crossover formation. Plant J. 2005;43(3):321–34." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR262" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6629">262</a>, <a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 263" title="Mercier R, Jolivet S, Vezon D, Huppe E, Chelysheva L, Giovanni M, Nogue F, Doutriaux MP, Horlow C, Grelon M, et al. Two meiotic crossover classes cohabit in Arabidopsis: One is dependent on MER3, whereas the other one is not. Curr Biol. 2005;15(8):692–701." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR263" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6632">263</a>]. <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> orthologs of these 16 genes were used as TBLASTN [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 105" title="Altschul SF, Madden TL, Schaffer AA, Zhang J, Zhang Z, Miller W, Lipman DJ. Gapped BLAST and PSI-BLAST: a new generation of protein database search programs. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997;25(17):3389–402." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR105" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6639">105</a>] queries against the version 2 assembly of the <i>A. glomerata</i> genome and additional publicly available green algal genomes (<i>Ostreococcus</i> sp. RCC809, <i>Ostreococcus lucimarinus</i> CCE9901, <i>Micromonas pusilla</i> CCMP1545, <i>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii</i> CC-503 cw92 mt+, <i>Volvox carteri</i> f. <i>nagariensis</i> Eve (HK10 derivative), <i>Chlorella variabilis</i> NC64A, <i>Coccomyxa subellipsoidea</i> C-169; JGI, 2013). If initial <i>A. thaliana</i> queries failed, subsequently identified green algal orthologs were used for additional queries. All genome hits were compared to the NCBI non-redundant protein database by BLASTX and, for putative orthologs of the 16 genes listed above, manually annotated with a predicted protein sequence based on <i>A. thaliana</i> and revisions following amino acid multiple sequence alignment comparisons (MUSCLE v3.6 [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 264" title="Edgar RC. MUSCLE: multiple sequence alignment with high accuracy and high throughput. Nucleic Acids Res. 2004;32(5):1792–7." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR264" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6677">264</a>], the MEGA5.05 interface of MUSCLE [<a data-track="click" data-track-action="reference anchor" data-track-label="link" data-test="citation-ref" aria-label="Reference 265" title="Tamura K, Peterson D, Peterson N, Stecher G, Nei M, Kumar S. MEGA5: Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis Using Maximum Likelihood, Evolutionary Distance, and Maximum Parsimony Methods. Mol Biol Evol. 2011;28(10):2731–9." href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#ref-CR265" id="ref-link-section-d4765e6680">265</a>]). Phylogenetic analyses (not shown) were done to test for orthology (e.g., distinguishing meiotic <i>Spo11–1</i> or <i>Spo11–2</i> from non-meiotic <i>Spo11–3</i>) and green algal origin (i.e., confirming that the putative <i>A. glomerata</i> orthologs fall into a clade with plants and green algae rather than fungal orthologs) using maximum likelihood (green algae and plants) or NJ (green algae, plants, select additional fungi) methods. This analysis identified 12 <i>A. glomerata</i> genes specific for meiosis and/or mitosis and one, <i>Spo11–3</i>, for endoreduplication (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a>).</p><p>The 314 candidate flagella proteins in <i>A. glomerata</i> (Additional file <a data-track="click" data-track-label="link" data-track-action="supplementary material anchor" href="/articles/10.1186/s12864-019-5629-x#MOESM5">5</a>) were identified by searching for putative orthologs among sequenced motile and non-motile chlorophytes using the reciprocal best BLASTP hit criterion (e-value&lt;1e<sup>− 5</sup>).
